Since this is my 100<\\/span>th<\\/sup> article on the Baltimore Orioles here on this new <\\/span>The Baltimore Wire<\\/span><\\/i><\\/b> web site since our inception on November 13<\\/span>th<\\/sup>, I thought I\\u2019d make it a dandy \\u2013 with multiple parts seeking to address multiple outstanding questions from spring training 2014.<\\/span><\\/p>\\n

After a wretched winter that continues to look like it refuses to end, it seemed that baseball would never return. And so it is still a bit shocking to the senses that we are in the final days of Grapefruit League play and that opening day is only now 11 days from now!<\\/p>\\n

With a total camp roster of 62 players, there has been, and continues to be, a lot of sorting in order to get to a 25-man Baltimore Orioles roster for the 2014 season. And along the way, the organization is also sorting players for continued development throughout the system \\u2013 particularly at AAA Norfolk and AA Bowie. The Orioles truly see their roster as more than 25 players, or even 40 players. They see it as 50-60 players in continual development toward helping the club in a given season. The \\u201cdeep depth\\u201d philosophy of Buck Showalter<\\/a><\\/strong> and Dan Duquette is difficult to criticize.<\\/p>\\n

So here are 10 current Baltimore Orioles roster types of questions that you can bounce through by clicking the arrow at the bottom-right corner of the pages \\u2026<\\/p>\\n

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 15, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles third baseman Manny Machado (13) in the dugout against the New York Yankees at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

When will Manny Machado be available, and what level of play may we expect for 2014?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

Machado is visiting the doctor in California today, and the organization hopes for a very positive report. The last week has certainly not gone exceedingly well.<\\/p>\\n

But even the best of news would make it almost unimaginable that the Orioles can get Manny ready to play in 10 days. Nor should they force this to happen.<\\/p>\\n

It is entirely unarguable that Manny Machado is anything but one of those extraordinarily rare talents that comes along only once in a great while. I think I have a creative and positive imagination for what is possible, but Machado\\u2019s 2013 season was WAY FAR beyond my wildest imaginations.<\\/p>\\n

There was no doubt that he should have started the season as the Orioles\\u2019 regular third baseman. He earned that from the final third of 2012. But I was very critical that Showalter was going to bat him second in the lineup. I would have told you that you were crazy if you said he would lead the league in doubles and be an all-star.<\\/p>\\n

And that does not even begin to address the defense. One thing about being an older guy doing an Orioles blog is this: I\\u2019ve seen with my own eyes just about every player that has ever worn the orange and black, including old #5 at the hot corner. And to put it in the political posturing terms of a few years ago, \\u201cI knew Brooks Robinson<\\/a><\\/strong>. Brooks Robinson was a friend of mine, and you, sir, are no Brooks Robinson!\\u201d\\u00a0 No, hear me on this \\u2013 supported by Brooks himself \\u2013 Machado is better! The glove may be equally the same, but Brooks never threw a baseball like this.<\\/p>\\n

So, there is no need to rush Manny back. Give him some extra weeks. Let\\u2019s shoot and hope for late April.<\\/p>\\n

But here is my real worry: It is not that Manny will get back later than that. I fear that he will not be the same person at all in 2014, due to spending the whole offseason getting repaired. I fear he will be irretrievably behind, and that we will not see the real Machado until 2015.<\\/p>\\n

The good news here is that I\\u2019ve been totally wrong about Manny before, and Machado is, as stated above, everything but normal. Maybe he can do incredible things again. That would be great!<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/3\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 1, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles second baseman Ryan Flaherty<\\/strong> (3) flips the ball in the second inning against the Toronto Blue Jays during a spring training exhibition game at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: David Manning<\\/strong>-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who will get the most starts at second base in 2014?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

It has been assumed throughout most of the offseason that Ryan Flaherty<\\/a> had earned the frontrunner position as the probable primary starter at second base for the 2014 Orioles. This could prove to be true. And it would be great for the Orioles to retrieve some strong benefits of their time investment in the 2012 Rule 5 pick.<\\/p>\\n

Flaherty has the requisite defensive skills for sure, and his power potential is well beyond the average second baseman. Yet his batting average and OBP have yet to instill confidence.<\\/p>\\n

It would certainly appear that Flaherty will now be starting the earliest games of the season at third base until Machado returns. And this versatility is what makes Flaherty ultimately so valuable for a team.<\\/p>\\n

Lighting up the offence at spring training has been young Jonathan Schoop<\\/a>. There is no doubt in anyone\\u2019s mind that Schoop has great upside potential. A spinal injury delayed his development last year, and his fall league play in Arizona was rather weak. But strength training and the filling out of aging beyond his teenage years has brought Schoop into camp with an entirely new body type \\u2026 and new offensive production.<\\/p>\\n

Orioles fans everywhere are excited about this and fill message boards with a \\u201cplay him now\\u201d theme. Perhaps Jonathon Schoop can be the second coming of Manny Machado. If that is so, and if Machado comes back as the fellow we remember from 2013, this could indeed be a special team.<\\/p>\\n

My guess is that Schoop will be kept if Machado is unable to open the season. As well, I would expect veteran infielder Alex Gonzalez<\\/a><\\/strong> to remain, as he has had an excellent spring season and seems ready to contribute well.<\\/p>\\n

Jamile Weeks \\u2013 who came from Oakland in the Jim Johnson<\\/a><\\/strong> deal \\u2013 has not hit well in camp, though he has shown an attractive ability to run the bases. But with an option remaining, that would appear to be his probable fate.<\\/p>\\n

Alexi Casilla<\\/a><\\/strong> has inherited Nolan Reimold<\\/a><\\/strong>\\u2019s bad luck cooties, and as much as Buck likes him, I don\\u2019t see how he will be kept in the end.<\\/p>\\n

Neither would there seem to be room for Rule 5 pick Michael Almanzar<\\/a><\\/strong>.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/4\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Jul 10, 2013; Baltimore, MD, USA; Baltimore Orioles catcher Matt Wieters<\\/strong> (32) congratulates pitcher Tommy Hunter<\\/strong> (29) after a game against the Texas Rangers at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. The Orioles defeated the Rangers 6-1. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who will be the Orioles closer?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

As always, before talking about closers, I feel obliged to throw out there my personal view that I don\\u2019t believe in designated closers, except in those rare occasions where a team has a \\u201clights-out\\u201d reliever. I don\\u2019t see that person on the Birds.<\\/p>\\n

However, since it is the craze to name a closer, I suppose we are going to be going with Tommy Hunter<\\/a> in this role. He indeed has the proper personality and mindset for this position. He has had some propensity for giving up the long ball, and that has been seen somewhat this spring.<\\/p>\\n

I would rather see a sinker-ball pitcher in the role, though the Orioles had that in the past with Jim Johnson \\u2013 who would often see hard-hit grounders through the infield put multiple runners on base. New addition Ryan Webb<\\/a><\\/strong> is such a pitcher. My hopes were\\/are that he may have sufficient success to end up in this role. I don\\u2019t see Darren O\\u2019Day as ever being that person.<\\/p>\\n

Interesting possibilities could be Zach Britton<\\/a><\\/strong> who has had a tremendous spring season. Or perhaps he could become part of the rotation, with Bud Norris<\\/a><\\/strong> moving to a 9th<\\/sup>-inning role. Other possibilities could be Suk-min Yoon or Alfredo Aceves<\\/a><\\/strong>.<\\/p>\\n

All in all, though Tommy Hunter could indeed prove to be a year-long success in this role, I fear it is going to take some sorting out before a final solution is settled upon. This could be the most painful part of this team to watch.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/5\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 12, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles pitcher Ubaldo Jimenez<\\/strong> (31) throws a pitch in the first inning of the spring training exhibition game against the Philadelphia Phillies at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Jonathan Dyer-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Will the starting rotation be a major upgrade over 2013? <\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

The answer to this question will provide the largest slice of explanation as to how successful the Orioles 2014 season will prove to be. There really is no successful model out there for a team to play at a high level without a solid rotation. Perhaps the closest anomaly would be the 2012 Orioles, where the bullpen carried the Birds to one unusual victory after another.<\\/p>\\n

There is every reason to see and believe Chris Tillman<\\/a><\\/strong> will serve as an effective top-of-the-rotation starter. But beyond him, there are as many questions as hopes.<\\/p>\\n

Ubaldo Jimenez<\\/a> is a good pickup for the Orioles if he pitches as he did at the end of last season. There have been extended periods of his career where he gets totally out of sync. He will need to control pitch counts in order to go deeply into games, and that could be difficult in the tough AL East where batters foul off pitch after pitch.<\\/p>\\n

Wei-Yin Chen<\\/a><\\/strong> is the only lefty in the presumed rotation. He too has mixed results. Just yesterday he turned in a less than stellar performance, though in spring training he may be concentrating on specific items of his repertoire without concern for compete results.<\\/p>\\n

Miguel Gonzalez<\\/a><\\/strong> has had some difficulty also in going deep into games, but he is consistent and looks to continue to grow and improve.<\\/p>\\n

Bud Norris has also been a starter with very mixed results. His time with the Orioles at the end of last year was less effective than his previous level of performance. He wants to be a regular starter for the whole season, but that will remain to be seen.<\\/p>\\n

Few teams have five starters who take the ball consistently throughout the year, and there is essentially a six- or seven-man rotation when it is all said and done. And the Orioles have as much depth as anyone for this scenario.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/6\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 11, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles relief pitcher Brian Matusz<\\/strong> (17) pitches during the fourth inning at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Tommy Gilligan-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Will the Orioles bullpen be an upgrade over 2013?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

As reliable as the bullpen was in 2012, it went the other direction in 2013. Expecting relievers to accomplish what the group did two years ago is to desire a very rare level of performance.<\\/p>\\n

However, there is reason to hope the pen will be better than last season.<\\/p>\\n

At this point, there are five \\u201clocks\\u201d to be part of the bullpen (discounting the trade of anyone) \\u2026 Zach Britton, Brian Matusz<\\/a>, Ryan Webb, Tommy Hunter, and Darren O\\u2019Day.<\\/p>\\n

The final two spots look to go to Josh Stinson<\\/a><\\/strong> \\u2013 who has performed well and is out of options \\u2013 and Alfredo Aceves.<\\/p>\\n

It would be nice to be able to find a way to keep nearby a couple of others in the organization \\u2013 like Brad Brach<\\/a><\\/strong> and Evan Meek<\\/a><\\/strong> for example.<\\/p>\\n

Suk-min Yoon will begin at Norfolk, being assigned there yesterday, though too much money has been spent to have the former Korean star stashed there for long.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/7\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 4, 2014; Tampa, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles left fielder David Lough<\\/strong> (9) triples during the third inning against the New York Yankees at George M. Steinbrenner Field. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who will get the most starts in left field in 2014?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

So what is the deal with Orioles left fielders having neck problems? This has been the story of Reimold\\u2019s life for longer than we would like to remember. And now David Lough<\\/a> has had problems with some odd and rather scary symptoms.<\\/p>\\n

But presuming these difficulties will soon be in the mirror for Lough, we can expect him to be in left field for more games than anyone else this year. The former Royals player is going to become a fan favorite at the Yard because of his aggressive style of play. He may even bat at the top of the order, but in any event he will provide some speed not typically seen by Orioles players in recent years.<\\/p>\\n

Against lefties, Reimold may get to play in left field. And though I\\u2019m as much of a Reimold supporter as can be found, I don\\u2019t believe he plays well on an occasional basis.<\\/p>\\n

Along with the DH discussion, something has to give with the logjam that exists still in camp for LF, DH, and utility outfielders. It is not looking good for Delmon Young<\\/a><\\/strong>. The speed and utility of Quintin Berry<\\/a><\\/strong> would be great to have, but is there room? Steve Pearce<\\/a><\\/strong> is loved by many, though not by me; but he additionally can play first base. Francisco Peguero<\\/a><\\/strong> will open on the DL, while Xavier Paul<\\/a><\\/strong> was assigned yesterday. And Henry Urrutia<\\/a><\\/strong> is destined to lead the International League in hitting for the first half of the season at least.<\\/p>\\n

With Lough in left field and Nelson Cruz<\\/a><\\/strong> as DH, along with regulars Markakis and Jones, certainly only two of the four \\u2013 Young, Pearce, Reimold, Berry \\u2013 can be kept. If up to me, I\\u2019d keep the latter two.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/8\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 15, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA;Baltimore Orioles right fielder Nelson Cruz (23) looks up after he was out at first base during the first inning against the New York Yankees at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who will get the most starts as the Orioles designated hitter in 2014?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

This won\\u2019t take long to answer. Nelson Cruz, of course.<\\/p>\\n

Showalter has spoken of playing him in left field against lefties \\u2013 in place of David Lough. This would put Reimold or Pearce in the lineup as DH.<\\/p>\\n

Certainly Cruz would be a better defender than Pearce, though I would think Reimold is the better option in LF than Nellie \\u2013 as they call Cruz.<\\/p>\\n

But there would seem to be no possibility of anyone DH-ing more than Cruz. And Showalter has already indicated in spring lineups that Cruz is likely to bat in the fifth spot in the order.<\\/p>\\n

Here at The Baltimore Wire<\\/i><\\/b> we are going to track DH stats and other positional stats \\u2013 especially in LF and 2B \\u2013 as compared to 2013 to see how much of an upgrade has been accomplished over 2013.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/9\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 16, 2014; Dunedin, FL, USA; Toronto Blue Jays first baseman Edwin Encarnacion<\\/strong> (10) slides safely into home plate as Baltimore Orioles catcher Steve Clevenger<\\/strong> (45) attempted to tag him out during the fourth inning at Florida Auto Exchange Park. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who will be the backup catcher?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

At first glance, given the assigning of Johnny Monell<\\/a><\\/strong> to AAA Norfoll, that Steve Clevenger<\\/a> has won this competition. Caleb Joseph<\\/a><\\/strong> is still in the camp, though he is not on the 40-man roster.<\\/p>\\n

There has been talk of someone outside the organization perhaps being brought in. This seems more than unnecessary to me, though, perhaps there is an incredible deal out there.<\\/p>\\n

Monell performed well in every way on both sides of the ball. Even so, Clevenger has been better, with 12 hits in 22 at bats.<\\/p>\\n

Every discussion of this role contains the caveat that, from the beginning, each was told that the position would be won on defense. Both have performed well, and Caleb Joseph has demonstrated great improvement in this part of his game also. There is no doubt that Joseph can hit, but the poor guy has been stuck in a sort of \\u201cGroundhog Day\\u201d of waking up in Bowie every game day for four seasons.<\\/p>\\n

The organization has come a long way in building catching depth, and with Wieters as a Boris client, this demonstrates good foresight.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/10\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 7, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA;Baltimore Orioles infielder Nick Markakis (21) hits a double during the spring training exhibition game against Philadelphia Phillies at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Jonathan Dyer-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

Who could be comeback players of the year for the Orioles?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

This begs the question as to who needs to make a comeback.<\\/p>\\n

The #1 answer to both questions is Nick Markakis<\\/a><\\/strong>. He is healthy for the first time in a while, he is in the best condition of his career, and Nick is fiercely infused with a competitive desire to prove he is still the great player he was a few years ago. He is also in the final year of a contract \\u2013 not that I honestly think that would make a difference in his approach.<\\/p>\\n

Nolan Reimold would love the redemption and vindication of finally putting it together. If I could make a wish for one player, it would be for Nolan. It could happen. It could also all fall apart, or never really return.<\\/p>\\n

Matt Wieters<\\/a> has seen his average drop year-to-year, and he has not provided the offensive production that was anticipated. Though I do see the great value he brings on defense, and I acknowledge his power for the position is at the top of his category; yet I don\\u2019t expect he will return to a .280 average or anything like that. I fear this is in the category of \\u201cit is what it is.\\u201d<\\/p>\\n

On the pitching side, looking very ready for comeback pitcher of the year is Zach Britton. Everything is working for him \\u2013 velocity, control, movement. This could be the pitching story of the year. Only a fool like me would write something like that; but if it turns out to be true, I\\u2019ll find this sentence to bring back in front of you again next fall.<\\/p>\\n

For most of the rest of the pitchers, simply definitive improvement would be enough to bring a playoff scenario to this powerful offensive team.<\\/p>\\n

<\\/p>"},{"title":"Baltimore Orioles Roster \\u2013 10 Items for the Next 10 Days","permalink":"http:\\/\\/thebaltimorewire.com\\/2014\\/03\\/20\\/baltimore-orioles-roster-10-items-next-10-days\\/11\\/","shortCodeTitle":null,"content":"

<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t

\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/a>\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t
\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t

Mar 15, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles first baseman Chris Davis (19) walks to the dugout after he stuck out during the second inning against the New York Yankees at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports<\\/p>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<\\/div>\\n\\t\\t\\n

What sort of encore season is reasonably possible from Chris Davis?<\\/i><\\/b><\\/p>\\n

Everyone asks Davis over and over if he can repeat last year\\u2019s performance. What\\u2019s he supposed to say? Yes? That would look arrogant. No? That would look weak.<\\/p>\\n

Davis has handled the situation well. He speaks of how wonderful the season was, and that, yes, since it was done once, it could be done again. That would not be impossible.<\\/p>\\n

We don\\u2019t actually need 53 homers and 138 RBIs from Crush. Even 35 and 115 would be fantastic, especially if accompanied by a higher batter average and decrease in strikeouts.<\\/p>\\n

Davis has worked on going the opposite direction and beating the mega-shifts that are deployed against him. Imagine if he did that and moved the defenses in the AL back to more standard positioning! Certainly he could then build a higher average, even in the absence of quite so stellar power statistics.<\\/p>\\n

HERE<\\/b><\\/a> is a video from yesterday of Jones beating that stinking Rays over-shift by stealing second and going right on to third base.<\\/p>\\n

CONCLUSION ON IT ALL \\u2013 It is a great time to be an Orioles fan!<\\/p>\\n

 <\\/p>\\n

[('Top 40 Orioles of All Time - #5, Frank Robinson - Camden Chat', ' #5 - Frank Robinson, OF (1966-1971) Frank Robinson comes in at #5 on the list of the Top 40 Orioles of All Time, but make no mistake: he was the best baseball player to ever put on an Orioles uniform. Hands down. Where he sits in baseball history is up for debate, but he is reasonably one of the top 25 players in MLB history.    When the Orioles traded for Frank Robinson in the winter of 1965, he was already a bonafide superstar. He had been Rookie of the Year, won an MVP, and had been to five All Star Games in his ten seasons with the Reds. From 1960-1962 he led the National League in slugging three straight years, and from 1961-1964 he lead the league in intentional walks. There is not much I can say about Frank Robinson that you all don\'t already know. When he arrived in Baltimore, he came to a team that was good, but not good enough to get to the playoffs. He\'s credited with giving them the boost they needed to win their first World Series. His first season was his finest in an Orioles uniform. He won the Triple Crown with the most home runs, runs batted in, and the highest batting average in the league. For good measure he also led the league in runs scored, on-base percentage, slugging percentage, total bases, and sacrifice fly. All that contributed to his cool 8.2 WAR that season. And he was just as great in the World Series against the Dodgers, where he took home the series MVP by going 4-for-14 with two home runs, a triple, three walks, four runs scored and three RBI.    By many accounts, Frank Robinson was one of the toughest, most intense players to play the game. If he was knocked down by a pitch, that made him more determined to hit one out, and he took out his aggression on the basepaths with vicious slides in the middle infield. Robinson led the league in getting hit by pitches seven times in his career, and it was revealed at one point that multiple managers charged their pitchers a fine if they hit Robinson on account of how Robinson took it out on the other team when he was.    There is little doubt that part of Robinson\'s hardness on the field was as a result of the racism he faced throughout his career. He played in the minors in the south where he was harassed regularly, and while playing in Cincinnati he received multiple death threats. Things didn\'t get better for him when he came to Baltimore, as he found it difficult to even find a place to live when he was traded. He was a superstar baseball player! A number of years ago I was gifted the book After Jackie. It\'s the story of black baseball players after the color barrier was broken, and the things that they went through in the careers. One chapter was dedicated to Frank Robinson, and in it he told a story about how he visited Baltimore with the Reds in 1958 for an exhibition game, but it got rained out so he decided to go to a movie. When he got to the ticket window they refused to sell him a ticket because it was a whites-only theater. He was in shock. Seven years later he was traded to the Orioles and he didn\'t want to go. He thought, "I\'ve got to move to Baltimore, and I\'m not going to be able to go to the movies."    I\'m not as tough as Frank Robinson, so that chapter left me crying. I\'m getting upset recalling it right now. That was the last chapter I read in the book. He went on to be a star in Baltimore and become a beloved member of the Orioles. He is revered in this town these days, and that\'s the way he was treated. After moving to Baltimore and not being able to rent a house in a good neighborhood because of the color of his skin, Frank Robinson became active in the civil rights movement. He made it his business to shed light on the discrimination and bigotry he faced, including on the field. But the discrimination he was subject to didn\'t affect him negatively on the field; if anything, it fueled him. In six seasons with the Orioles, Robinson hit .300/.401/.543 (OPS+ 169) with 179 home runs, 143 doubles, and 460 walks. His wOBA was .415, wRC+ 168. He never once had an OPS+ of less than 151. He helped lead the Orioles to four World Series in six years.    Traded to the Los Angeles Dodgers after the 1971 season, Frank Robinson went on to play five more seasons with the Dodgers, Angels, and Indians. In 1975 the Indians named him player-manager, making him the first African-American manager in the history of baseball. He was back with the Orioles in a front-office position in the mid-1980s, and in 1988 replaced Cal Ripken Sr. as manager. He managed the Orioles through that terrible season and the awesome 1989. He lasted 37 games into 1991 before being replaced. In the recent past, Frank Robinson has been absent from the Orioles family, which is sad. But he returned in April 2012 as his statue was revealed, and in his speech to the crowd he prophetically spoke of a time in the near future when the young talent on the Orioles would come together and be very good. Just a few weeks ago, he made an appearance at spring training to talk to the current Orioles. He wore an orange polo shirt that he joked had been in retirement until a few years ago. When the Orioles created their team Hall of Fame in 1977, Frank Robinson and Brooks Robinson were inducted together as the first two members. In 1982, the first year he was eligible, he was voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame with 89.2% of the vote. Despite ten great years with the Reds, he went into Cooperstown in an Orioles cap. He is one of the greatest players in baseball history and the 5th greatest Oriole of all time. Additional sources: SABR Baseball Biography Project, FanGraphs, Baseball Reference  ', 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles sign Luis Ayala - Birds Watcher', 'General Manager Dan Duquette is always watching the waiver wire, just as a good baseball executive should. So when Washington released former Oriole Luis Ayala and his representative immediately contacted the Baltimore Orioles, Duquette pounced. The O\xe2\x80\x99s are prepared to announce today that they\xe2\x80\x99ve signed Ayala to a minor league contract with an invitation to spring training. Ayala of course played for the Orioles in 2012, on the team that went to the playoffs for the first time in 14 years. He was 1-0 out of the pen, but he was also a right-handed specialist that really came through for the Birds in the clutch when they needed clean innings in games.Photo: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsAyala was traded to Atlanta (from the Orioles) early last season. During his first stint here, he posted a 3.27 ERA with six strikeouts per nine innings, and 3.5 walks per nine innings. Ayala\xe2\x80\x99s contract is expected to be a \xe2\x80\x9csplit deal\xe2\x80\x9d in the sense that there will be certain incentives built in if he\xe2\x80\x99s pitching at the big league level. There might also be an opt out clause if he\xe2\x80\x99s not in the majors by a certain date. The O\xe2\x80\x99s are viewing this as a depth move, and Ayala could also be stashed at Norfolk for some time if the organization wants to keep him pitching more often in case he\xe2\x80\x99s needed once the season starts. The Orioles traded Ayala to Atlanta early last year in exchange for pitching prospect Chris Jones, who\xe2\x80\x99s still with the Orioles organization. [("Bartolo Colon's bat does the talking in start - USA TODAY", 'Bartolo Colon signed a two-year deal with the Mets.(Photo: Brad Barr, USA TODAY Sports)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREJUPITER, Fla. \xe2\x80\x93 Bartolo Colon threw 6 2/3 innings of two-run ball in his next-to-last outing of the spring, making his case for starting on Opening Day for the New York Mets, and his pitching performance hardly caused a ripple of excitement.His hitting? Now, that was the talk of the game.DOWN UNDER: Dodgers win openerColon, who hasn\'t had a hit in the majors since 2005, made contact in three of four at-bats and had an RBI single \xe2\x80\x93 a hard grounder past third base and into the left-field corner that would have been a double for anybody else \xe2\x80\x93 in the Mets\' 10-2 win over the Miami Marlins."I told him if he hits one of those in Miami, he better try to get to second because it\'s a long way out there,\'\' manager Terry Collins said. "He may hit fifth if he continues to hit good.\'\'Colon is a .104 career hitter \xe2\x80\x93 10-for-96 \xe2\x80\x93 in 16 seasons mercifully spent almost exclusively in the American League, except for a three-month stint with the Montreal Expos in 2002.But now that he\'s facing a full season of having to step up to the plate \xe2\x80\x93 if not necessarily hit \xe2\x80\x93 Colon could use some practice, and he got plenty as the Mets pounded Marlins pitchers for 13 hits.His first time up, the 40-year-old Colon didn\'t even pretend to swing as he struck out looking on three pitches, and that figured to be his hitting approach the rest of the game.But something happened between the second inning and the fourth, when Colon hit a slow comebacker for an easy out that still elicited a lively response from the Mets dugout and their fans behind it.Then in the sixth, Colon ripped a 93 mph fastball from Henry Rodriguez for the RBI single."Really, the ball found the bat,\'\' Colon said. "I really didn\'t do anything.\'\'The 5-11, 265-pound Colon did have to run the bases, as Eric Young Jr. followed with a deep drive to center that wound up hopping over the fence for a ground-rule double.That sight of Colon motoring around drew some chuckles, but Collins said not to be deceived by his girth."This guy\'s a better athlete than what he\'s teasing you about. Don\'t get too caught up in that,\'\' Collins said. "This guy\'s got great feet, he\'s got great hands. He knows when he\'s got to do something right.\'\'Like keeping his legs healthy instead of blowing out a hamstring trying for a hit. In his final at-bat in the seventh, Colon hit a slow dribbler to third that the vast majority of the baseball population would have turned into an infield single. He was thrown out at first."Honestly, I was a little scared,\'\' Colon said of running the bases in general. "I haven\'t done that in a while. Thankfully nothing happened.\'\'GALLERY: GRAPEFRUIT LEAGUEFacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInGrapefruit League photos from spring training\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. You may also like these photo galleries:Replay1 of 822 of 823 of 824 of 825 of 826 of 827 of 828 of 829 of 8210 of 8211 of 8212 of 8213 of 8214 of 8215 of 8216 of 8217 of 8218 of 8219 of 8220 of 8221 of 8222 of 8223 of 8224 of 8225 of 8226 of 8227 of 8228 of 8229 of 8230 of 8231 of 8232 of 8233 of 8234 of 8235 of 8236 of 8237 of 8238 of 8239 of 8240 of 8241 of 8242 of 8243 of 8244 of 8245 of 8246 of 8247 of 8248 of 8249 of 8250 of 8251 of 8252 of 8253 of 8254 of 8255 of 8256 of 8257 of 8258 of 8259 of 8260 of 8261 of 8262 of 8263 of 8264 of 8265 of 8266 of 8267 of 8268 of 8269 of 8270 of 8271 of 8272 of 8273 of 8274 of 8275 of 8276 of 8277 of 8278 of 8279 of 8280 of 8281 of 8282 of 82AutoplayShow ThumbnailsShow CaptionsLast SlideNext SlideCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('When do the Baltimore Orioles unveil Manny Machado?', 'One of the biggest questions for the Baltimore Orioles in spring training has been the status of third baseman Manny Machado. Will he be ready for Opening Day? When will we actually see him in a game? I\xe2\x80\x99ve maintained since January that my personal opinion was that Machado would start getting into games towards the end of spring training, would probably be sent to extended spring training once the team broke camp, go out on a rehab assignment, and eventually rejoin the O\xe2\x80\x99s towards the end of April to guard the hot corner. The Orioles haven\xe2\x80\x99t yet publically said that Machado wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to be ready on Opening Day, however at this point that appears to be a bit of a stretch.Machado was examined by\xc2\xa0Dr. Neal ElAttrache in Los Angeles this week, and he returned toCourtesy of Kim Klement-USA TODAY SportsSarasota yesterday after the good doctor cleared him to resume workouts. Machado no longer has any medical restrictions. However Buck Showalter hasn\xe2\x80\x99t said when we\xe2\x80\x99ll actually see Machado in a game. Anyone that\xe2\x80\x99s seen how Showalter operates since he\xe2\x80\x99s been with the Birds knows that there\xe2\x80\x99s usually more than meets the eye going on in his brain. My point is that I suspect that Showalter and Dan Duquette have a plan in place in terms of when Machado will start playing, how much work he\xe2\x80\x99ll get, etc.All Orioles fans want to see Machado at Camden Yards on Opening Day. However I would submit that Machado playing on Opening Day might not be in the best interests of the organization. Granted every situation is different, however I recall that in 2010 Brian Roberts was bothered by back spasms for most of camp and didn\xe2\x80\x99t start playing in games until the final week or so of spring training; we all know how that turned out. Roberts strained his back in the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 home opener, and quite frankly hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been the same since.Obviously Roberts was an aging veteran at the time, and Machado is a budding star. He\xe2\x80\x99s also more important to the organization than Roberts was at the time of his injury. However my point is that often rushing someone back after being hurt causes more harm. So as I said, I suspect we\xe2\x80\x99ll see Machado stay in Sarasota after the Orioles pack up and leave at the end of next week, and play in a few extended spring games. He\xe2\x80\x99ll probably then head up perhaps to double-A Bowie (only for proximity reasons) for rehab starts before joining the Orioles in late April.Miguel Gonzalez became the first Oriole starter to pitch six innings in a spring training game yesterday as the Birds defeated Atlanta 8-0. Gonzalez was moved up a day in the \xe2\x80\x9crotation\xe2\x80\x9d (so-to-speak) due to Chris Tillman coming down with a 24-hour flu bug that\xe2\x80\x99s made it\xe2\x80\x99s way through the clubhouse. Unfortunately this is something that we often see in baseball given the amount of time the players spend together. Ubaldo Jimenez will get the ball this afternoon when the O\xe2\x80\x99s head to Port Charlotte, FL to take on the Tampa Rays. ', 'birdswatcher.com')]

[('Baltimore Orioles: Two More Minor League Signings', 'Troy Taormina-USA TODAY SportsSome people call it dumpster diving, others call it organizational depth.\xc2\xa0 Dave Trembley, above with Brett Wallace, would have liked a little more organizational depth when he was in Baltimore.Dan Duquette and the Baltimore Orioles just continue to shop for more players. A few days ago, the team signed Luis Ayala, who the Orioles had traded to Atlanta for Chris Jones. Ayala struggled away from Baltimore, but now is back with a minor league deal.Saturday, the team announced they had reached an agreement on a minor league deal with David Adams. Adams, who started 38 games last year for the New York Yankees, is a very polished fielder. He is not quite as strong with his bat, hitting .193 in 2013 with 27 hits and 13 RBIs.Adams was for the Cleveland Indians this spring, appearing in 17 games and getting 9 hits in 32 at-bats for a .281 batting average. Adams, 27, is likely to be another utility infielder in the Orioles organization. And with some of their other utility options, such as Alexi Casilla and Alex Gonzalez either making the team or possibly opting out, the Orioles will need that depth.But, that\xe2\x80\x99s not all. The Orioles announced today (Sunday) the signing of Brett Wallace to a minor-league deal. Wallace, a corner infielder, was the first round pick by the St. Louis Cardinals in 2008.Wallace has played 311 major league games in his career, all with the Houston Astros. He is a career .242 hitter, with 29 home runs. Wallace, also 27, is a guy who strikes out a lot, but some think he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t quite figured it out yet. He does have several good hitting years in the minor leagues.Dan Duquette, speaking of the signing to MASN Sports\xe2\x80\x99 Roch Kubatko, said the following about Wallace, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you look at his numbers in the minors, he\xe2\x80\x99s hit over .300 there. It hasn\xe2\x80\x99t translated as effectively to the big leagues, so maybe a little more time will help with that. He can hit. He hit 24 home runs last year between Triple-A and the big leagues.\xe2\x80\x9dI like both signings. Neither are guys who are going to make the Opening Day roster, but you never know when injuries could become an issue. And let\xe2\x80\x99s face it, the positional depth among the Orioles minor leagues is a weakness, so bringing in some capable players is not a bad thing.The team has a lot of decisions in the next eight days to get the team from the current number of players in major league camp to 25 for Opening Day. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: What is Wieters worth? - Birds Watcher', 'Mar 8, 2014; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles catcher Matt Wieters (32) hits an RBI single during the second inning against the Boston Red Sox at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Tommy Gilligan-USA TODAY SportsI\xe2\x80\x99m torn, as many Orioles fans are, about a potential contract extension for two-time all-star catcher Matt Wieters. On one hand, I love certain things about Matt Wieters. I\xe2\x80\x99ll laugh when a poor lost soul tries to swipe second. I\xe2\x80\x99ll laud Wieters for his ability and desire to catch every day. I love his positive attitude and his handling of the wide range of Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 pitching \xe2\x80\x94 from inexperienced super talents like Kevin Gausman, to over-the-hill finesse pitchers like Joe Saunders.Then he comes to the plate.Once considered a prime hitting prospect Wieters has not lived up to the \xe2\x80\x9cSwitch-Hitting-Jesus\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cMauer-With-Power\xe2\x80\x9d monikers. Some have wondered whether he should give up the switch-hitting part altogether. No one draws the comparison to the perennial .300-hitting Joe Mauer anymore.Instead, the Orioles get a healthy 20 home runs per year and a not-so-healthy batting average. Last year, the real killer was a bottom-scraping .287 on-base-percentage coupled with his career-low .235 average. Even second baseman and utility infielder Ryan Flaherty, who many would argue was the worst hitter on last year\xe2\x80\x99s Orioles team, bested Wieters\xe2\x80\x99 lowly OBP.When it comes down to it, the Orioles are paying for two good-to-very-good attributes from Wieters, his power and his defense. But how much is that worth, and how much is that offset by his below average production in other areas.From early indications, Wieters\xe2\x80\x99 agent Scott Boras seems to think that Wieters is worth a lot. According to ESPN\xe2\x80\x99s Buster Olney, Boras proposed an extension somewhere in the range of the eight-year, $184 million deal that Mauer signed before the 2013 season.In 2012, 29-year-old catcher Yadier Molina signed a five-year, $75 million extension with the St. Louis Cardinals. At the time, Molina had won four consecutive Gold Gloves and made the All-Star team three times. He was coming off a 2011 season where he hit .305/.349/.465 over 139 games and his career was trending upward.Wieters put up comparable numbers to Molina earlier in his career, batting .262/.328./.450 and .249/.329/.435 in 2011 and 2012, respectively, while hitting 22 and 23 home runs during those seasons. Before his backslide in 2013, I would have said that Wieters deserves similar money. But now, giving Wieters a contract worth the same average annual value as Molina ($15 million per year) seems like overpaying for an inferior performance.Before this season, Wieters and the Orioles agreed to a one-year, $7.5 million deal to avoid arbitration. Paying much more than that is becoming increasingly less attractive for the Orioles and their fans. While having Wieters around is great for now, he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t done enough to warrant a long term deal on the same level that he\xe2\x80\x99s reportedly asked for. What he brings to the table, defense and power, are two things the Orioles currently have a surplus of. If the team needs to cut costs to sign other stars like Chris Davis, catcher may be the position to do it. It can afford to bring in a replacement-level player, perhaps Baltimore product Steve Clevenger, to handle duties behind the plate in a couple years. He may actually be an improvement on offense given the way that Wieters performed last year.If Wieters continues to show that he may not be worth a high-cost long-term commitment with his play this year, the Orioles are left with two options: make Wieters a qualifying offer when he walks in 2015, thus recouping a first-round draft pick, or trade him.Either way, Matt Wieters should not be a Baltimore Oriole beyond the 2015 season unless his contract demands dramatically decrease. Stellar defense and power are great, but at what cost? The Orioles have more important paydays coming up in Davis and Manny Machado. Despite what he\xe2\x80\x99s done for the Orioles, its becoming apparent that the best option is for the pair to part ways. I\xe2\x80\x99ll miss Matt Wieters when the Orioles are in the field, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad to see his name out of the batting order and off the Orioles books. ', 'birdswatcher.com')]

[('Baltimore Orioles: Dan Duquette Does It Again', 'Steve Mitchell-USA TODAY SportsAlright, let\xe2\x80\x99s not even try to sugar coat things, Dan Duquette may be a genius.\xc2\xa0 Who else trades a 37-year-old who hasn\xe2\x80\x99t played more than 50 games in two seasons for a player who is already a proven utility player on a winning team?\xc2\xa0 That\xe2\x80\x99s what I thought.Alex Gonzalez deserves a lot of credit for this.\xc2\xa0 He had a GREAT spring for the Baltimore Orioles, and now is rewarded by a starting spot on what I believe is one of the top three teams in the AL, the Detroit Tigers (with the Orioles and Boston Red Sox). Gonzalez was 12-28 this spring for a .429 average, and is always a good fielding option.\xc2\xa0 In fact, Buck Showalter commented Monday that Gonzalez was going to make the Orioles as a utility infielder had he not been traded.But in return, the Orioles get Steve Lombardozzi Jr.\xc2\xa0 There is a lot to like here for Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 fans.First, Lombardozzi comes from a baseball family, as his dad was a major leaguer.\xc2\xa0 Also, he lives in Columbia, Maryland and grew up going to Orioles games.Lombardozzi is only 25-years-old, a significant 12 years younger than Gonzalez.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0He also is under team option until 2018.Lombardozzi can play second base, third base and the outfield, and is a switch-hitter.\xc2\xa0 He played in over 100 games in each of the last two seasons for the Washington Nationals, hitting .273 and .279 respectively.While his numbers aren\xe2\x80\x99t going to wow you, he presents much more to the Orioles future than a 37-year-old.\xc2\xa0 And with the Tigers being a team built to win now, this trade in the end does make some sense for both teams.But I still think that the Orioles won this trade easily.\xc2\xa0 Remember, Lombardozzi was the biggest name traded to Detroit when they traded Doug Fister to the Nationals.What else this trade means is several things for players currently vying for a roster spot.\xc2\xa0 Let\xe2\x80\x99s face it, Ryan Flaherty is going to be on the roster.\xc2\xa0 One would believe Lombardozzi will be too, even though he has minor league options.\xc2\xa0 So that means Alexi Casillia, for one, is likely gone.\xc2\xa0 Jonathan Schoop is likely headed to AAA, which will allow him to prove his spring training after bulking up is no fluke.Jemile Weeks will probably also be headed to AAA Norfolk, while Michael Almanzar likely is headed to back to the Red Sox, unless the Orioles can work out a trade.\xc2\xa0 And I think that is a high possibility, and I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be shocked if it is Weeks who goes to the Red Sox. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('David Adams, Brett Wallace \\u2013 Baltimore Orioles Pick-ups', '\xc2\xa0May 22, 2013; Baltimore, MD, USA; New York Yankees third baseman David Adams (39) hits a solo home run in the ninth inning against the Baltimore Orioles at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. The Orioles defeated the Yankees 6-3. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsIs Dan Duquette the Imelda Marcos of the Baltimore Orioles? The who? Some of you reading this are likely too young to remember the wife of The Philippines\xe2\x80\x99 ousted Dictator Ferdinand Marcos. She garnered worldwide fame for her excessive lifestyle when it was revealed that she left behind over 1200 pairs of shoes. So does DD collect and horde ballplayers in this fashion?Or maybe a better illustration is a do-it-yourselfer dude and Home Depot. At some point when I got a credit card there, I became an email client where I get a daily \xe2\x80\x98deal of the day\xe2\x80\x99 notification. I suppose some men cannot resist running into the orange box store and making the most of the sale, whether they need that tool or not! Is that the way Duquette is with the waiver wire?Over the weekend the Orioles have signed two infielders to minor league deals: former Yankees second baseman David Adams \xe2\x80\x93 who was claimed off waivers from the Indians, and Brett Wallace \xe2\x80\x93 a corner infielder who played portions of four seasons with the Astros.Probably most Orioles fans wonder \xe2\x80\x9cwhy?\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0Why get these guys with very marginal statistics who are so unlikely to really make an impact, and who sometimes clog up the system? Actually, these are not players who clog the system, as the Orioles do need to fill out the position player roles with sufficient level-appropriate talent throughout the organization.And yes, most of these acquisitions are long-shot types, and each of these most recent additions are in their age 27 year. But a common theme for both Adams and Wallace \xe2\x80\x93 and almost always with these deals \xe2\x80\x93 is that they were high draft choices. There was something about them in terms of their past performances and athleticism that had them valued so highly, and perhaps something will at long last click and they will put the pieces together such that the Orioles really have something.Some years ago I had befriended a young man who was a minor league player for the Hagerstown Suns when they were a Toronto affiliate. He was a late-round draft pick but was hitting very well \xe2\x80\x93 well into the .300s, whereas another top-round draftee hitting 100 points less was advanced up the system instead. Noting this situation, I remember the guy telling me, \xe2\x80\x9cTop draft picks will be given innumerable opportunities to prove that can\xe2\x80\x99t do it, whereas a late-round guy like me will only have a short window of time to prove that we can.\xe2\x80\x9dSo that is some of what we are seeing here with these, and other choices. But let\xe2\x80\x99s look at and comment on the stats \xe2\x80\xa6David Adams career stats \xe2\x80\x93 all from 2013 Yankees \xe2\x80\xa6YearAgeTmGPAABRH2B3BHRRBISBCSBBSOBAOBPSLGOPS201326NYY4315214010275121300943.193.252.286.537\xc2\xa0Maybe a reason for Duquette to get Adams into the Orioles organization is because he was a short-term Birds killer. Notice that his two career home runs are against Baltimore \xe2\x80\x93 the one team he hit well against. And notice that the picture above is of one of his homers at Oriole Park.David Adams stats against the Orioles \xe2\x80\xa6SplitGGSPAABRH2B3BHRRBIBBSOBAOBPSLGOPSBaltimore Orioles87282337002255.304.429.565.994\xc2\xa0David Adams career minor league stats \xe2\x80\xa6YearAgeTmLgGPAABRH2B3BHRRBISBCSBBSOBAOBPSLGOPS200821NYY-minA-672972574566192431823257.257.350.393.743200922NYY-minA,A+132569490691404087751186188.286.373.443.816201023NYY-minAA391731523147153332521831.309.393.507.900201124NYY-minRk,A+29121108194012011523918.370.421.509.931201225NYY-minAA8638332744100230848313853.306.385.450.834201326NYY-minAAA592552202859112521002943.268.366.405.771\xc2\xa0Brett Wallace was only 2-for-14 with the Astros this spring. He was a first-round, #13 overall pick in 2008 and has a career .242 average. Here are his career numbers.YearAgeTmLgGPAABRH2B3BHRRBISBCSBBSOBAOBPSLGOPS201023HOUNL5115914414326121300850.222.296.319.615201124HOUNL1153793363787220529113691.259.334.369.703201225HOUNL662542292458101924001873.253.323.424.746201326HOUAL79285262355814113361118104.221.284.431.7164 Yrs3111077971110235523291022280318.242.313.391.704\xc2\xa0For more thoughts and perspectives on these players, see our Baltimore Wire writer Nate Wardle\xe2\x80\x99s excellent piece HERE.\xc2\xa0 ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Tigers acquire Alex Gonzalez from Orioles - USATODAY.com', 'Alex Gonzalez is a career .246 hitter who turned 37 last month.(Photo: Kim Klement, USA TODAY Sports)                              13                      CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREThe Detroit Tigers, who likely will be without Jose Iglesias for the season, have acquired veteran shortstop Alex Gonzalez from the Baltimore Orioles for utility man Steve Lombardozzi. The move was first reported by the Baltimore Sun.Both players were starting their first seasons with their teams.NIGHTENGALE: Ausmus stays stoic amid grim springGonzalez, 37, has played 15 seasons in the major leagues, for the Florida Marlins, Boston Red Sox, Cincinnati Reds, Toronto Blue Jays, Atlanta Braves and Milwaukee Brewers.He has 157 career home runs and a .246 career batting average. Last season, he had one homer, eight RBIs and a .177 average over 41 games (113 at-bats) with the Brewers. He played first base (22 games), third base (11 games) and shortstop (three games), compiling a .974 fielding percentage.Gonzalez appeared in 12 games for the Orioles this spring and batted .429 with four runs, one double, two home runs and six RBIs.Lombardozzi was acquired from the Washington Nationals in the off-season Doug Fister trade.A valuable utilityman, Lombardozzi figures to be in the mix for significant playing time at second base with the Orioles, who were considering prospect Jonathan Schoop for the job. Veteran Ryan Flaherty also figures to get some playing time there.The Tigers on Friday traded for Los Angeles Angles shortstop Andrew Romine, in another attempt to find a replacement shortstop. Internal candidates Hernan Perez and Danny Worth also remain in the running.Jahnke writes for the Detroit Free PressGALLERY: Scenes from the Grapefruit LeagueFacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInGrapefruit League photos from spring training\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.
