                    });                 });             }          } })();  Jim Palmer, the Hall of Fame pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, grew up a Yankees fan in New York. One of his fondest memories is of his father taking him to his first game at Yankee Stadium in 1954. The Indians were playing the Yankees. He was amazed at how the field glowed.\xe2\x80\x9cIt rained,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cso the grass was even greener.\xe2\x80\x9dPalmer eventually made his own memories in major league parks around the country. His r\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 includes 268 victories, a .638 winning percentage, eight 20-win seasons and a 2.86 earned run average in 19 seasons. He is the only pitcher to win World Series games in three decades, in 1966, 1970, 1971 and 1983. He won three Cy Young Awards and four Gold Gloves. He threw a no-hitter against Oakland in 1969 and was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1990.Palmer, 68, now a television commentator for Orioles games, expects the team to contend for the playoffs.His charity work includes support for Autism Speaks, the autism advocacy organization, and for B.A.T., or the Baseball Assistance Team, which helps former players and baseball employees who have fallen on hard times. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Q. How do you spend your time away from baseball?A. In the winter, my wife, Susan, has a shop in Palm Beach \xe2\x80\x94 Island Home. I help her there. My stepson, Spencer, is autistic. He\xe2\x80\x99s 17 and I take him to school and we go to the gym and I do a lot of things with him. I do a lot of fund-raising in Palm Beach and support Autism Speaks.Q. Is there a pitcher who reminds you of you?A. Michael Wacha of the Cardinals has a similar windup. He comes over the top and throws hard. He has the big curveball. We both got to the big leagues very early.Q. What do you think of the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 additions of Nelson Cruz and Ubaldo Jimenez?A. I was at the Orioles Fanfest and said to Dan Duquette, \xe2\x80\x9cAh, the most well-rested G.M. in baseball.\xe2\x80\x9d I have that kind of relationship with him. He started laughing. He said hopefully we\xe2\x80\x99re not done. Then they go out and get Jimenez and Cruz. Jimenez had a great last 16 games last year. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s power will help replace Nate McLouth offensively, although he won\xe2\x80\x99t be as good defensively or give you the same speed.I love their core players: Matt Wieters, Adam Jones, Chris Davis, J. J. Hardy, Nick Markakis, who was not healthy last year, Manny Machado. Brooks Robinson told me, I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure if Machado\xe2\x80\x99s not better than I was. That\xe2\x80\x99s quite a statement. I see them as contenders.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Q. How do you think Masahiro Tanaka will do for the Yankees?A. Culture, strike zone, facing the best hitters on the planet. Yankee Stadium is not easy to pitch in. There\xe2\x80\x99s always an adjustment period. The Yankees would be very pleased if he pitched as well as Yu Darvish has.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Q. What do you think about Derek Jeter\xe2\x80\x99s retiring?A. Baseball is going to miss him. He\xe2\x80\x99s one of the transcendent players. I\xe2\x80\x99ve played with Eddie Murray, Frank Robinson, Brooks Robinson and Cal Ripken Jr. They\xe2\x80\x99re graceful, have a tremendous work ethic. Reliable. I once asked Derek, your lifetime average is what, .312? You almost hit the same with runners in scoring position. He looked at me and he said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what changes?\xe2\x80\x9d The mind-set of Derek Jeter was that it didn\xe2\x80\x99t matter what stage he played on. He was able to be the same player and do it for 20 years. You are already subscribed to this email. View all New York Times newsletters.   See Sample Manage Email Preferences Not you? Privacy Policy     Q. Any regrets?A. The love/hate relationship that I supposedly had with Earl Weaver. I wish I had been a little more mature in my relationship with Earl. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure it would have changed anything. That and the fact that you learn not to judge people by your standards. When I got to the Hall of Fame I gave him a lot of credit. Any time a manager puts your name in the starting lineup as the pitcher that means he trusts you. And Earl did it over a 10-, 11-, 12-year period.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Q. What hitter who was not a star player gave you the most trouble?A. Doug Griffin. I pitched away and he loved the ball out over the plate. He was an outside-half hitter. That all changed when Nolan Ryan hit him in the helmet. He stopped diving.Q. What do you think of the expanded use of replay review?A. They\xe2\x80\x99re going to have to fine-tune it to make sure they don\xe2\x80\x99t make the game longer. But it\xe2\x80\x99s in the spirit of trying to get the calls right. It\xe2\x80\x99s embraced by baseball, and the umpires want to get calls right. Being an umpire is probably the most difficult thing in baseball. I know it\xe2\x80\x99s tough to hit 97-mile-an-hour pitches, curves and sliders. But every time you make a call, you\xe2\x80\x99re going to make somebody unhappy.Q. Should players who used performance-enhancing drugs be allowed in the Hall of Fame?A. Cal Ripken Sr. once told me when I was 18 years old \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99re all in Class A, making $414 after taxes, living in basements, trying to get to Double A \xe2\x80\x94 there are no such things as shortcuts. In a perfect world, they don\xe2\x80\x99t get in even though there are some deserving guys who were Hall of Fame players. They just decided to take shortcuts. I\xe2\x80\x99m not a baseball writer, but I would be more inclined to vote for the guys who used them and still were Hall of Fame caliber players.The most difficult thing is how are you going to hurt the Barry Bondses of the world, the Roger Clemenses, who did not need to do anything? The writers at some point might say Bonds was going to get to the Hall of Fame, but he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to hit 73 home runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  And if they let anybody who used performance-enhancing drugs in, then Pete Rose ought to get in the same year.Q. Would Major League Baseball welcome an openly gay player?A. I see no reason why not. The great thing about baseball is you can really be a zebra, but it\xe2\x80\x99s about if you can play or not. It\xe2\x80\x99s not about race or sexuality.Q. What\xe2\x80\x99s on your iPod?A. My wife is a George Strait fan, and I listen to him. I listen to Dean Martin and Frank Sinatra. They bet on the Orioles in 1966, 40 to 1, to win four straight. A thousand dollars. And the next year I got invited to see Frank at the Fontainebleau in Miami Beach in spring training. But, unfortunately, they play a lot of Sinatra at Yankee Stadium when they beat the Orioles.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  This interview was condensed and edited. Continue reading the main story       We\xe2\x80\x99re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.                 ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('The Real Baltimore Orioles Arrive North in NYC', '\xc2\xa0Apr 8, 2014; Bronx, NY, USA; Baltimore Orioles catcher Matt Wieters (32) runs the bases after hitting a home run against the New York Yankees at Yankee Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Camporeale-USA TODAY SportsBeing a migratory species of fowl, the Baltimore Oriole can\xe2\x80\x99t really be expected to be seen much in cold weather. And sure enough, when a decently warm day for baseball finally arrived, so did the real Baltimore Orioles who laid a 14-5, 20-hit spanking upon the Yankees. This is the baseball team we expected to see!Orioles fans everywhere are hoping that this is the big breakout game that launches the offensive attack for the 2014 season. Everyone in the Orioles starting lineup got into the act. We could continue to pick on Ryan Flaherty by noting that he was the only starter to not register a RBI, although he was one of three Orioles to get three hits in the game. And the Birds broke out with three homers as well: by Adam Jones, Delmon Young, and Matt Wieters.As further proof that Buck Showalter reads my columns and takes advice for the next day, he noted my wise suggestion from yesterday that Young should be put in the lineup \xe2\x80\x93 having stellar numbers historically against Yankees starter Ivan Nova. Young batted second in the lineup and had three hits and three RBIs.Young may get some more playing time, as David Lough is being reported to be headed to the DL for (at this point) undisclosed reasons, with Jemile Weeks being recalled. Weeks was 6-for-12 in his first four games at AAA Norfolk with two triples.Pretty much everything went right for the Orioles offense on Tuesday. The bottom three guys in the order \xe2\x80\x93 Steve Lombardozzi, Flaherty, and Jonathan Schoop were a combined 8-for-15. That is when you know your team is having a good day!It is also great to see Matt Wieters hitting well at the beginning of this new season. This was one of the concerns coming into 2014 \xe2\x80\x93 that Wieters was never going to live up to the hopes for offensive output that were placed upon him when he first arrived in Baltimore. Right now he is batting .370 through the first eight games \xe2\x80\x93 10-for-27 with two homers and six RBIs.But not lost in the euphoria was another rather poor outing for an Orioles starter. Chen was able to get the win after pitching through five tortuous and torturous (twisting and painful) innings, giving up four runs on nine hits \xe2\x80\xa6 and now having an ERA of 6.75. This will have to change.The Orioles will be facing the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 new pitching sensation Masahiro Tanaka in the series finale on Wednesday evening. In only his second game, Tanaka won his first outing over the Blue Jays 7-3. He gave up two earned runs in seven innings of six-hit pitching, while recording eight strikeouts.Baltimore continues to look for a pitcher other than Chris Tillman to throw a decent game, and the next man up is Miguel Gonzalez. His first outing was difficult, as the Tigers drubbed him with seven runs on nine hits in just 3.1 innings of work.Gonzalez may draw some additional inner fortitude and strength in that he will certainly be cognizant of pitching on the fifth anniversary of the tragic death of his friend Nick Adenhart. The two knew each other from their days in the Angels organization, and Gonzalez used a glove belonging to Adenhart in his first start for the Orioles two years ago. In that Nick is from my town of Williamsport and was a classmate and friend of one of my sons, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have an additional article (to follow this one) on the Maryland native.In seven career games against the Yankees, Gonzalez is 2-2 with a 4.01 ERA. His WHIP is a very solid 1.17 and the batting average against is but .224 \xe2\x80\x93 all good numbers against New York. As can be seen in the chart below however, a number of the current Yankees have had some success against Gonzalez even considering the small sample size. Both Ichero Suzuki and Alfonso Soriano have a pair of homers off him.PAABH2B3BHRRBIBBSOBAOBPIchiro Suzuki20194102315.211.250Brett Gardner15124300022.333.429Derek Jeter12114010111.364.417Kelly Johnson1193100123.333.455Jacoby Ellsbury663100100.500.500Alfonso Soriano552002301.400.400Francisco Cervelli310000020.000.667 ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles Take the Series in New York', 'Apr 9, 2014; Bronx, NY, USA; Baltimore Orioles second baseman Jonathan Schoop (6) is congratulated by Baltimore Orioles catcher Matt Wieters (32) after hitting a three run home run against the New York Yankees during the second inning at Yankee Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Adam Hunger-USA TODAY SportsGame 9: Baltimore Orioles 5 (4-5) New York Yankees 4 (4-5) FW: Brian Matusz (1-0)L: Shawn Kelley (0-1)S: Tommy Hunter (3)MVP: Brian Matusz \xe2\x80\x93 W, 2/3 IP, stranded a runner at 3BThe GOOD: Jonathan Schoop\xe2\x80\x99s 3-R HR off of Masahiro Tanaka. Schoop made the Earl of Baltimore proud with the three-run bomb, and that kind of production from the 9 hitter is always welcomed.\xc2\xa0 Then there was the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 ninth inning.\xc2\xa0 An inning of beauty! The Orioles keep producing in the 9th, and they tagged Shawn Kelley with numerous bloops to bring in two runs. Delmon Young turned in another solid game, going 3-5 with a double. Matt Wieters kept his hitting streak to start the season going as well. Eight of the nine Orioles that started had hits, only Nelson Cruz was hitless. Miguel Gonzalez did pretty well, save for the second inning.\xc2\xa0 More on that below.\xc2\xa0 But speaking of pitchers, how about Brian Matusz.\xc2\xa0 Comes in with a man on third and one out, and it is the speedy Brett Gardner. And he goes nowhere.\xc2\xa0 Ellsbury pops out in foul territory to Schoop and then Brian McCann hits it to Adam JonesThe BAD: Miguel Gonzalez\xe2\x80\x99s two solo home runs allowed.\xc2\xa0 Yes it didn\xe2\x80\x99t lose the Orioles the game, and it is always better that they are solo, but it is painful to watch them come right after the Orioles took a three run lead.\xc2\xa0 Also, the approach by several hitters was off tonight.\xc2\xa0 Nick Markakis decided he wanted to swing at the first pitch he saw from Tanaka in each at-bat. Because of it, he saw an average of less than two pitches an at-bat.\xc2\xa0 That is awful coming from your leadoff hitter.\xc2\xa0 Also, Tanaka used his nasty splitter to strike out the Orioles ten times, and several of those were on ugly at-bats.\xc2\xa0 None more so than Chris Davis, who with a man on swung at two pitches that bounced around the plate and then struck out looking.\xc2\xa0 In fact, it was only Steve Lombardozzi and Ryan Flaherty who did not strike out in the game.\xc2\xa0 The save wasn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly clean or pretty, but it ended up alright!What\xe2\x80\x99s NEXT: The Orioles get an off-day on Thursday before they come back to Baltimore to take on the Toronto Blue Jays (5-4 and play the Astros tomorrow at 7 p.m.) The matchup will feature Dustin McGowan vs. Bud Norris, at least that is who I expect to start.\xc2\xa0 Neither one looked good in their first starts, as both have ERAs of 9 and over.\xc2\xa0 As of writing this, the Jays are in the lead in the AL East, and are the only team over .500.\xc2\xa0 Which is surprising, considering that their team statistics are not good for either the hitters or the pitchers. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Orioles Rally In 9th To Beat The Yankees 5-4 \\xab CBS Baltimore', ' NEW YORK (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 Masahiro Tanaka made Adam Jones look silly in his first two at-bats. Still, the All-Star center fielder who is always at the ready with a not-so-safe opinion wasn\xe2\x80\x99t all that impressed by the young Japanese pitcher. Nick Markakis had an RBI single in the ninth inning against fill-in closer Shawn Kelley, and the Baltimore Orioles rallied for a 5-4 victory Wednesday night over the New York Yankees after wasting a three-run lead against Tanaka. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not the same hitters he faced over there. We groove, we hack,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jones, who struck out twice before getting a single in his three at-bats off Tanaka. Jonathan Schoop hit a soaring three-run homer off Tanaka in the second inning of the right-hander\xe2\x80\x99s first start at Yankee Stadium but Carlos Beltran and Kelly Johnson connected against Miguel Gonzalez in the bottom of the inning. Alfonso Soriano tied it with a groundout in the fourth. \xe2\x80\x9cHe just made a mistake, kept a slider up,\xe2\x80\x9d Schoop said. \xe2\x80\x9cI tried to make adjustments as he tried to elevate me, and then he made a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d The Orioles, who managed only seven hits while striking out 10 times against Tananka in seven innings, lined four straight hits to center field off Kelley, pitching the ninth for the second time in place of the injured David Robertson. Ryan Flaherty and Schoop each lined 0-2 pitches from Kelley (0-1) and Markakis singled in Flaherty and, after Delmon Young got his third hit of the night, Chris Davis made it 5-3 with a sacrifice fly. \xe2\x80\x9cI felt like they did a good job getting the barrel to some good pitches,\xe2\x80\x9d Kelly said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I bounced some of those balls, maybe they\xe2\x80\x99re swing and misses.\xe2\x80\x9d Tommy Hunter gave up two hits to start the ninth and a sacrifice fly to former Oriole Brian Roberts before getting Yangervis Solarte to ground into a double play for his third save, finishing off the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 second straight win over New York. Brian Matusz got two outs (1-0). Matusz has stranded 51 of 56 inherited runners dating to 2012, a major league best. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not always going to be pretty, you just look at the result,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. Jones came up to a smattering of boos before his first at-bat a day after he said, \xe2\x80\x9cThey should let us have a shot to kick `em with our metal spikes,\xe2\x80\x9d about two fans who ran on the field Tuesday. The fans\xe2\x80\x99 shenanigans got a huge cheer from the crowd. Jones fanned his first two times up to hardy cheers. Jones wasn\xe2\x80\x99t alone. Tanaka had the Orioles flailing at his nasty split-fingered fastball all night, many bouncing in the dirt. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is as good as advertised,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said of Tanaka. There were many empty seats on a brisk night in the Bronx despite it being New York\xe2\x80\x99s first chance to see the prized Tananka, who signed a seven-year, $155 million contract with the Yankees this winter \xe2\x80\x94 plus a $20 million rights fee paid to his team in Japan, Ratuken. Tanaka warmed up to the bubbly \xe2\x80\x9cMy Dear Fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d a song written for the 25-year-old pitcher by the Japanese group Momoiro Clover Z. He then received a rude welcome from Markakis. The Orioles leadoff batter grounded the first pitch of the game right back at Tanaka, hitting him on the foot before it deflected to shortstop Derek Jeter, who made the throw for the out. In similar fashion to his first big league start at Toronto, Tanaka was tagged early before settling in. He gave up three runs \xe2\x80\x94 two earned \xe2\x80\x94 in the first two innings Friday of a seven-inning outing in which he struck out eight. This time, Schoop hit a soaring three-run homer high above the left field pole in the second inning. But Tanaka gave up just three more singles and a walk. Gonzalez was equal to the task, allowing seven hits and three runs. He walked one and struck out three. NOTES: Tanaka\xe2\x80\x99s walk of Wieters in the third snapped a streak of five straight games in which the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 starter did not allow a walk. \xe2\x80\xa6 Orioles OF David Lough passed a concussion test in Baltimore earlier in the day. He came in as a defensive replacement in the ninth. Jemile Weeks was brought to the Bronx from Triple-A Norfolk and was in the clubhouse Wednesday in case Lough was placed on the disabled list. \xe2\x80\xa6 Orioles LHP Johan Santana (shoulder) will pitch BP Saturday in Sarasota, Fla. \xe2\x80\xa6 RHP Dylan Bundy (Tommy John surgery) threw 35 fastballs. Manager Buck Showalter said it went well. \xe2\x80\xa6 Up next: The Yankees begin a four-game series against Boston Thursday. Michael Pineda (1-0) makes his first Yankee Stadium start. The Orioles open a series against Toronto in Baltimore on Friday. (Copyright 2013 by The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.)  0.000000 0.000000   var addthis_product = \'wpp-261\'; var addthis_config = {"data_track_clickback":true};if (typeof(addthis_share) == "undefined"){ addthis_share = {"url_transforms":{"shorten":{"twitter":"bitly"}},"shorteners":{"bitly":{"login":"cbslocal","apiKey":"R_bfe2742f79bb4091b0fcfbdf5c6a81ca"}}};}  ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com')]

[('Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by Tanaka - The ...', '     Supported by    Baseball  Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by Tanaka    On Baseball  By                       TYLER KEPNER   APRIL 10, 2014     Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }        Nelson Cruz smirked at the question, more irritated than amused by the suggestion that he might have been curious to see Masahiro Tanaka in person. The hype of a $155 million contract and another pinstriped sensation from Japan did not do much for Cruz, the Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 left fielder.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s another day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou take it like another day \xe2\x80\x94 business, like usual.\xe2\x80\x9dThat was as fitting a summary as any for Tanaka\xe2\x80\x99s debut at Yankee Stadium. The game was well-attended \xe2\x80\x94 39,412 paid \xe2\x80\x94 but not a sellout. It was the first night game at home this season, but without any pageantry or obvious passion in the chilly spring air. The Yankees never had a lead and lost, 5-4.\xe2\x80\x9cSeven innings, three runs, 10 strikeouts \xe2\x80\x94 that\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty good line,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Adam Jones, accurately reciting Tanaka\xe2\x80\x99s statistics for the night. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we had some great at-bats off him. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got to give him some credit, but we didn\xe2\x80\x99t make it easy on him.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Orioles pushed Tanaka to a draw with one swing from their own rookie, Jonathan Schoop, a 22-year-old infielder from Cura\xc3\xa7ao. With two on and two out in the second inning, Tanaka hung a slider and Schoop launched it down the left-field line, into a mostly empty section in the second deck for his second career home run. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cI shocked them? Why?\xe2\x80\x9d Schoop said, smiling, to the Japanese reporters around his locker. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a good pitcher. He just made a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Orioles rapped seven hits against Tanaka, and a few other hard-hit outs. They also took some wild swings on balls in the dirt, underscoring the quality of Tanaka\xe2\x80\x99s repertory. The Orioles expected him to be around the strike zone, and he was, walking just one.Jones disputed the idea that Tanaka had struggled, and asked rhetorically if Tanaka, who was 24-0 in the regular season in Japan last season, was supposed to be perfect.\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t happening here,\xe2\x80\x9d Jones said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got good stuff, though. Can\xe2\x80\x99t say he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t. He\xe2\x80\x99s a strike thrower. He\xe2\x80\x99s attacking the zone early, and with two strikes he knows how to put you away.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jones struck out on a fastball in his first at-bat \xe2\x80\x94 94 miles an hour, but straight \xe2\x80\x94 and on a splitter his next. He singled off a fastball his third time up, in the fifth, before Tanaka retired his last seven hitters.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Cruz also struck out twice \xe2\x80\x94 on sliders, he said \xe2\x80\x94 as Tanaka became the first Yankee to strike out at least eight batters in each of his first two major league starts since Allen Russell in 1915. Privacy Policy     Russell went 26-36 over five seasons with the Yankees, before they ever won a World Series. The expectations are much greater for Tanaka, and so far he has not disappointed. He has 18 strikeouts in 14 innings, with a 3.21 earned run average.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe can pitch to all quadrants of the plate,\xe2\x80\x9d catcher Brian McCann said after the game. \xe2\x80\x9cHe can elevate you. He can change eye levels with a slider or a split. He\xe2\x80\x99s got all the pitches to be top of the rotation.\xe2\x80\x9dJones mentioned that the Orioles had already faced a few aces, like Justin Verlander and Jon Lester, and he did not declare Tanaka to be in their class. That caliber of pitcher, Jones said, was the standard Tanaka now faces in the American League, and particularly in the East, where all the teams look dangerous.Cruz, who played with Yu Darvish in Texas, said it was too early to compare Tanaka to Darvish. The Orioles were more comfortable comparing Tanaka to another Yankee, Hiroki Kuroda. They noticed the similarities when studying Tanaka\xe2\x80\x99s first start, in Toronto, and did not sound surprised by what they saw live.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHim and Kuroda are very, very similar,\xe2\x80\x9d Jones said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think Kuroda throws a little more sinkers as opposed to Tanaka \xe2\x80\x94 he\xe2\x80\x99s more four-seamers \xe2\x80\x94 but very similar stuff. They\xe2\x80\x99re competitors.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jones added: \xe2\x80\x9cWe faced Kuroda a couple of days ago, so we knew a little of the similarities and we went over them before the game. We had an idea and tried to stick with our plan. It worked. We had a chance to get a little bit more off him, but we were able to get what we got.\xe2\x80\x9dThey got enough, from Schoop\xe2\x80\x99s blast, to chase Tanaka from the game with a tie score in the seventh. Tanaka might have lasted longer in Japan, but cutting off a start after 100 pitches is another adjustment over here.\xe2\x80\x9cI understand there\xe2\x80\x99s only four days in between starts, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a very long season,\xe2\x80\x9d Tanaka said through an interpreter. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to listen to what the team has to say.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on April 10, 2014, on Page B17 of the New York edition with the headline: Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by a New Yankee. ', 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles Minor League Pitching Report \\u2013 Bowie \\u2026', '\xc2\xa0Nov 2, 2013; Surprise, AZ, USA; Baltimore Orioles pitcher Eduardo Rodriguez against the East during the Fall Stars Game at Surprise Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Mark J. Rebilas-USA TODAY SportsFrom time to time over the course of the season, here at The Baltimore Wire we will give some updates on the pitching rotations at AAA Norfolk and AA Bowie. In that pitching is such a big and critical part of the game of baseball, it is always good to be able to know what is just over the horizon in terms of future prospects to take the mound for the Baltimore Orioles.The system-wide emphasis on pitching is seen extending to the AA affiliate in Bowie, Maryland, where pitching coach Blaine Beatty has some great young arms to work with. Beyond that, Dylan Bundy could well be re-entering the sport through the Bowie Baysox before too long.Currently through seven games, Bowie is 5-2, with three of the top prospects in the Orioles system are a part of the current rotation \xe2\x80\xa6#3 prospect Eduardo Rodriguez \xe2\x80\x93 has been off to a bit of a rough start in his two games so far. He has given up four earned runs over five innings in both of his starts. Hopes are high for the young man who is still only age 21. He made it to Bowie at the end of last season, pitched especially well in Arizona for the fall league, and looked impressive in spring training big league camp.#6 prospect Tim Berry \xe2\x80\x93 Buck Showalter can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to stop talking about how impressed he is with the 23-year-old. Taken in the 50th round, he has already been through arm problems and Tommy John surgery \xe2\x80\x93 hence his low placement in the draft. His first outing was a fantastic seven innings of three-hit baseball. \xe2\x80\x9cThe change-up was working for me today,\xe2\x80\x9d Berry said. \xe2\x80\x9cI was commanding it well and it had better action than it usually has. You mix that with the fastball and that\xe2\x80\x99s really all you need to keep hitters off balance. My curveball I just kind of sprinkled in.\xe2\x80\x9d#11 prospect Zach Davies \xe2\x80\x93 Bowie pitching coach Blaine Beatty told me before spring training started that he was especially excited to work with Davies this year. Also at age 21, Davies is unusual for pitching prospects because of his size \xe2\x80\x93 listed at 6-0 and 150 pounds. He was a 26th-round pick in 2011, but has great control of his pitches. His first game was reasonably good with only two runs in five innings. This is his first shot at the AA level.Jake Pettit had a difficult start in his first outing, as the first five batters he faced hit five consecutive singles. He did manage to hold the damage to a total of four runs over four innings. Pettit is a career minor leaguer in the Orioles organization who has thrown a total of 491 innings with a 36-21 record and 3.77 ERA. He was a 42nd-round pick in 2010.Tyler Wilson threw six shutouts innings in his first start, giving up only three hits. \xe2\x80\x9cEspecially in your first start of the year, it\xe2\x80\x99s great to get out there and get those nerves out of the way,\xe2\x80\x9d Wilson said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou really want to find your rhythm early on, no matter what start, but especially in the first start of the year.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0 Wilson is a 2011 selection of the Orioles in the 10th round out of UVA. Now age 24, he spent most of last season with Bowie as he works through the O\xe2\x80\x99s farm system.Also getting a start was 27-year-old Matt Bischoff, a pitcher who spent most of 2013 with the Baysox, appearing in 25 games \xe2\x80\x93 all but one in relief. He was originally drafted by the Mariners out of Purdue University. He is a minor league free agent that was signed by the Orioles in January, 2012. He is not to be confused with the bearded character of the same name who gained notoriety on the TV series \xe2\x80\x9cSurvivor.\xe2\x80\x9dAgeGGSWLIPHRERBBSOHRERAWHIPTim Berry23117.03101700.000.571Matt Bischoff272115.02110911.800.400Zach Davies211115.05223503.601.600Jake Pettit271114.07442309.002.250Eduardo Rodriguez21221110.013983707.201.600Tyler Wilson241116.03001500.000.667 ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Baseball-Major League Baseball roundup - yahoo.com', 'April 10 (The Sports Xchange) - Chicago White Sox outfielder Avisail Garcia is out for the season with a torn labrum in his left shoulder that will require season-ending surgery.Garcia, 22, is scheduled to undergo season-ending surgery "within the next week," the White Sox said Thursday. Garcia was injured Wednesday at Colorado attempting to make a diving catch in the sixth inning. He landed awkwardly and was removed from the game.- -Manager Bob Mevlin said Thursday that the Oakland Athletics will use a closer by committee until offseason acquisition Jim Johnson regains command and confidence.Johnson, traded to the Athletics from the Baltimore Orioles, understands the demotion, Melvin said Thursday before the series finale against the Minnesota Twins. Johnson\'s ERA is 18.90 in five games this season, including a blown save and two losses. He had 101 saves in the previous two seasons, best in baseball.- -Cleveland Indians third baseman Lonnie Chisenhall was placed on the paternity list and Justin Sellers was recalled to fill his roster spot.Sellers, 28, was acquired on March 2 from the Los Angeles Dodgers and appeared in 13 games with Cleveland in the spring training, hitting .450 (9-20) with three doubles and three RBIs.(Editing by Frank Pingue) ', 'www.yahoo.com')]

[('Baltimore Orioles: The ballpark experience - Birds Watcher', 'Yesterday for the first time since March 30th, the Baltimore Orioles were off. But don\xe2\x80\x99t worry; the Birds are back in action tonight back at the yard against Toronto! In monitoring the first two weeks of league play, 0ne thing across Major League Baseball that\xe2\x80\x99s struck me is that there have been a few complaints about the experience at the ballpark. The O\xe2\x80\x99s have only played three games at home to this point, however I think that most people around here would agree that fans know what they\xe2\x80\x99re getting when they buy a ticket to Oriole Park at Camden Yards. Overall, I think that most fans would agree that not only\xc2\xa0is the in-game experience good in Baltimore, but that it\xe2\x80\x99s gotten better.But in reading various columns and even fan boards, I see a general level of contempt from fans across the league when they go to MLB games. Whether it\xe2\x80\x99s long lines at the concession stands, bathrooms, ticket windows, etc., customer service issues, or anything else, it appears that teams are doing a better job of getting under fans\xe2\x80\x99 skin. So what gives? What should be done about this, and/or what can be done?This is always a tough sell because people come at this type of thing from different vantage points. However one common denominator I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen in fan complaints is long lines at concession stands. Those types of things are universally seen as bad. Part of the problem is that many teams/vendor companies can\xe2\x80\x99t accurately predict what their attendance is going to be game in and game out. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy enough to say that attendance is going to be lower in months such as April or September, or higher in general on weekends. However it\xe2\x80\x99s very difficult to gauge what kind of walk-up crowd a game is going to draw. So if they\xe2\x80\x99re expecting 15K and the game ends up drawing a huge walk-up crowd, odds are that staffing levels at concession stands, souvenir shops, etc. will be lower than necessary which will provide for longer waits.Unfortunately the age of the game itself being the only draw is probably over. For so many years fans would flock to Memorial Stadium \xe2\x80\x93 just to watch the game. But now with the concept of the \xe2\x80\x9cballpark experience,\xe2\x80\x9d people look for more than that. Again, for the most part I think that the Orioles do a good job with this. Whether you\xe2\x80\x99re a casual fan or a die hard, one thing that is necessary is customer service. And I\xe2\x80\x99m not talking about someone having to wait 20 minutes for a hot dog, I\xe2\x80\x99m referring more to just the overall attitude of the workers at the park. If ushers are rude or cop attitudes with fans, it\xe2\x80\x99s going to dissuade people from coming back. Granted when you\xe2\x80\x99re dealing with the general public that\xe2\x80\x99s not always easy, however believe it or not that might well be the easiest part of improving the ballpark experience.Going back to lines at the concession stands for a moment, many of the newer parks actually have open concourses now (Nationals Park in Washington, along with Harbor Park in Norfolk \xe2\x80\x93 home of the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 triple-A team \xe2\x80\x93 are two examples). While it\xe2\x80\x99s not perfect, that might help to alleviate some of the \xe2\x80\x9cpain\xe2\x80\x9d for fans associated with missing part of the game. Granted I remember when it was novel to have televisions or the radio feed pipped into the concourse, however the fact is that\xe2\x80\x99s no longer good enough. Fans pay to see the game in person, not on TV in the concourse area.Courtesy of Bob DeChiara-US PRESSWIREUltimately teams probably need to take a look at how their gameday experience operates across the board. It\xe2\x80\x99s also worthwhile for executives to take in games as fans at other parks, just to see if they can catch onto things that other teams are doing and so forth. This is not to say that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t already happen, however it\xe2\x80\x99s not a bad idea. I say all of this fully recognizing that in some cases people\xe2\x80\x99s perceptions can be based on things beyond the team or anyone else\xe2\x80\x99s control. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard fans in other sports complainin that \xe2\x80\x9cthe\xc2\xa0[insert team name]\xc2\xa0need to do something about the construction on the roads outside the stadium. That makes it much more difficult to get to the game.\xe2\x80\x9d Common sense people. Having said that, attitudes as such just illustrate why teams need to do their best to perfect things that they\xc2\xa0can\xc2\xa0control.The Orioles return home tonight to open up a six-game homestand with Toronto in for the weekend. Buck Showalter reshuffled his rotation a bit, which he was able to do given the team\xe2\x80\x99s off day yesterday. Chris Tillman will get the start tonight on normal rest following his gem of a game last Sunday in Detroit. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be opposed by Dustin McGowan of Toronto. The hope is that J.J. Hardy will be back in the lineup tonight after missing four games with neck spasms. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Blue Jays 2, Orioles 0: The defense sucks, the baserunning ...', " These are the kinds of games that make you hate baseball. \xc2\xa0Or hate Manny Machado and J.J. Hardy for being hurt. \xc2\xa0Or hate Buck Showalter for putting the weakest defender of the three reserves who must start at the hot corner. \xc2\xa0No matter who you choose to hate, you hate the Orioles, because Chris Tillman's brilliant, ace-like outing was wasted on a game full of bad defense, bad baserunning and all-around bad baseballing.    Let's start with Chris Tillman, because Chris Tillman didn't suck. \xc2\xa0At all. \xc2\xa0Chris Tillman threw eight brilliant innings, allowing zero earned runs with six K's to just one walk, and needed just 105 pitches to do it. \xc2\xa0And he basically would've thrown a nine-inning shutout if not for the defense, but we'll get to that. \xc2\xa0Aside from getting into a few too many two- and three-ball counts in the early innings, there was absolutely nothing to criticize about Tillman's pitching tonight. \xc2\xa0He had the Blue Jays off-balance and hitting into weak contact all night long. Not to take anything away from Tillman's counterpart, Dustin McGowan, who pitched a hell of a game himself. \xc2\xa0McGowan allowed more baserunners than Tillman, throwing 6 1/3 scoreless with five hits, one walk and just two strikeouts, but he kept the Orioles off-balance as well. \xc2\xa0The Orioles got some warning-track flyballs, and they gifted McGowan a scoreless inning (more on that in a moment as well), but he did what he needed to do and the Orioles didn't make him pay for any of his mistakes. The fourth and fifth innings were the pivotal moments in this game. \xc2\xa0In the fourth inning, the Orioles defense suddenly chose to remind us that Manny Machado and J.J. Hardy are really important to the Orioles defense. \xc2\xa0Both Blue Jays runs in the game were unearned, and there were three awful throws to allow them, even though only two errors showed up on the scorecard. \xc2\xa0First, Jose Bautista reached base on a grounder to third. \xc2\xa0Jonathan Schoop's throw sailed over Chris Davis's head to allow the runner onto base. \xc2\xa0After a clean single from Edwin Encarnacion put runners on first and second, Schoop made another throwing error on an Adam Lind grounder, letting Bautista score. \xc2\xa0The indignity was complete on a tailor-made double-play ball where Ryan Flaherty bounced the second throw past Chris Tillman, who was covering first base, allowing the second run to score when the inning should have ended.    Schoop might be the young guy on the roster right now, but I hope he's buying Tillman a nice steak tomorrow. For all that the defense let the team down, baserunning blunders didn't help. \xc2\xa0If the defense had supported Tillman's sturdy pitching performance, a smart fifth inning could've granted the Orioles a run. \xc2\xa0With two outs, the team put up consecutive well-hit singles from Nick Markakis, Delmon Young and Chris Davis. \xc2\xa0But on Davis's single, third base coach Bobby Dickerson held up Nick Markakis at third, while right fielder Bautista came up slowly and threw to third, assuming that Markakis was an automatic run. \xc2\xa0Adam Jones came up with the bases loaded and lofted a soft fly ball to center to end the two-out rally. There's an alternate reality where the Orioles won an exciting pitcher's duel, 1-0, based on sturdy defense, timely hitting and sharp baserunning. \xc2\xa0Then there's the reality I ended up in, where I hate everything. \xc2\xa0Chris Tillman, you are awesome. \xc2\xa0The rest of you Orioles have officially let me down.     ", 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Chris Tillman Looks to get Orioles Back to Even', '\xc2\xa0Apr 6, 2014; Detroit, MI, USA; Baltimore Orioles starting pitcher Chris Tillman (30) pitches against the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park. Mandatory Credit: Rick Osentoski-USA TODAY SportsAfter Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s off day, the season continues on Friday evening with game 10 against the Toronto Blue Jays. The Baltimore Orioles have won three of the past four games to pull themselves to a record of 4-5 in the AL East, where all five teams are within a game of each other. The Orioles will look to improve upon their 10-9 record against the Jays in 2013.The day off allows the Orioles to pitch Chris Tillman in the opening game of the series on his normal five-day schedule. Bud Norris will bump back with two extra days and pitch on Saturday, while Ubaldo Jimenez goes Sunday with one extra day.The most recent two games in New York seemed to feature the rediscovery of the Orioles offense, and that makes all the difference. The bottom of the order has been especially effective, and I suppose that any team that had their 7-8-9 hitters go 12-for-27 over a two-day period is going to have a lot of success.It is also presumed that J.J. Hardy will likely be recovered sufficiently from his back spasm issues to play again, and likewise David Lough has hopefully put the concussion-like symptoms behind him and can play at a high level.The Orioles will be facing Toronto hurler Dustin McGowan in the first game of the series. Other than Adam Jones being 4-for-5 off him, there is not much else in terms of optimistic numbers \xe2\x80\xa6 though few have faced him many times. However, Delmon Young is only 1-for-14, Nick Markakis is 0-for-10, and Nelson Cruz 0-for-5. Ryan Flaherty has a homer in two at bats, and he will surely be facing McGowan.PAABH2B3BHRRBIBBSOBADelmon Young14121000113.083Nick Markakis12101000021.100Nelson Cruz540000002.000J.J. Hardy551100102.200Adam Jones554100100.800Matt Wieters440000001.000Ryan Flaherty2110011101.000Steve Clevenger1111002001.000\xc2\xa0McGowan has only pitched once this season, when on April 4th against the Yankees he gave up four runs on eight hits over just 2.2 innings, taking the loss in a game with a final score of 7-3.Tillman has established his team ace credentials in his two outings to kick off 2014. In the final game against Detroit and Justin Verlander, Tillman pitched what might have been his best game ever \xe2\x80\x93 going 8.1 innings and giving up only a solo homer and one run on five hits. This followed his opening day start against Boston with a run over five innings. So his current ERA is 1.35.Over his career, Chris Tillman is 3-3 in 10 games against the Jays, with an ERA of 3.86 and an excellent WHIP of 1.170. A number of the Toronto hitters have pretty decent career numbers against him. Cody Rasmus is 6-for-14 with two homers, while Jose Bautista is 6-for-18 with two long balls as well\xe2\x80\xa6PAABH2B3BHRRBIBBSOBAAdam Lind29278000227.296Edwin Encarnacion26257101113.280Jose Bautista21186102428.333Colby Rasmus14146202401.429Brett Lawrie13133001103.231Melky Cabrera12113101402.273Ryan Goins661000101.167Maicer Izturis320000010.000Dioner Navarro220000001.000\xc2\xa0So even though the long-term career numbers favor McGowan in this game, I am thinking the more recent performances of each gives Chris Tillman and the Orioles in Camden Yards the advantage. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com')]

[('Baltimore Orioles Minor League Pitching Report \\u2013 Norfolk \\u2026', '\xc2\xa0Mar 13, 2014; Tampa, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles starting pitcher Kevin Gausman (39) throws a pitch during the fifth inning against the New York Yankees at George M. Steinbrenner Field. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY SportsFrom time to time over the course of the season, here at The Baltimore Wire we will give some updates on the pitching rotations at AAA Norfolk and AA Bowie. In that pitching is such a big and critical part of the game of baseball, it is always good to be able to know what is just over the horizon in terms of future prospects to take the mound for the Baltimore Orioles.It has been presumed that the Orioles are rather well-armed with high-level pitching prospects and that the AAA Norfolk rotation was going to be rather outstanding. So far, that has been a mixed bag of results. The team is not hitting particularly well other than Jemile Weeks and Caleb Joseph, and they are off to a 3-5 start through the first eight games. (Caleb Joseph had a 12th-inning two-run double last night to make a winner out of newly-acquired pitcher Preston Guilmet.)Tides manager Ron Johnson stated at the beginning of the season that his rotation was going to go in this order: Kevin Gausman, Steve Johnson, T.J. McFarland, Suk-min Yoon, and Mike Wright. This plan was upset before it even started, as weather uncertainties in Detroit caused fears of a possible Orioles-Tigers double header last Saturday (which did not eventuate) and Gausman was pulled from the opener to head toward Michigan. Eddie Gamboa made the start for Norfolk instead. He pitched well, allowing two runs in five innings \xe2\x80\x93 those runs coming on a two-run homer with two outs in the 5th inning. We\xe2\x80\x99ll mention Gamboa again later.Of the starting rotation so far this year \xe2\x80\xa6Kevin Gausman \xe2\x80\x93 Considered the #2 Orioles prospect, he is clearly on a strict pitch count around 70-75. His first start went 4.2 scoreless innings with three hits, two walks, and six strikeouts. His second start was more difficult with two earned runs over four innings with four hits and two walks.Steve Johnson \xe2\x80\x93 He threw 55 pitches in his first outing, doing so over three innings with three hits and a run given up. His second outing on Friday night was more difficult. In 4.2 innings he was touched up for four runs on four hits \xe2\x80\x93 two of them homers, raising his ERA to 5.87.T.J. McFarland \xe2\x80\x93 The Orioles Rule 5 draftee from last year had a very good first start and will pitch again Saturday. Over four innings he gave up one run on four hits, while striking out five.Suk-min Yoon \xe2\x80\x93 This is not encouraging. Lasting only 2.1 innings, Gwinnett got to him for nine earned runs on 11 hits. That translates to a 34.71 ERA. Hopefully he had food poisoning or something like that affecting him. My readers may recall that I have not been an optimistic person about Yoon, though I want to be terribly wrong about my fears. Eddie Gamboa game into the game and went 5.2 scoreless innings to bring things under control. As you can see in the chart below, Gamboa now has an ERA of 1.69.David Wright \xe2\x80\x93 The Orioles Minor League Pitcher of the Year in 2013 had a very strong first start, going five innings and giving up but one run on five hits. He also had four strikeouts.Here are the current numbers of the six pitchers discussed today\xe2\x80\xa6Player\xc2\xa0W\xc2\xa0L\xc2\xa0ERA\xc2\xa0GS\xc2\xa0IP\xc2\xa0H\xc2\xa0R\xc2\xa0ER\xc2\xa0HR\xc2\xa0BB\xc2\xa0SO\xc2\xa0WHIP\xc2\xa0Kevin Gausman002.0828.273205101.38Eddie Gamboa011.69110.292211110.94Steve Johnson005.8727.27552381.39T.J. McFarland002.2514.04110051.00Mike Wright000.0015.05100141.20Suk-min Yoon0134.7112.111991105.14 ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ("After blown save, Orioles' David Lough hits walk-off single", 'David Lough is surrounded by teammates after hitting the game winning RBI single in the twelfth inning.(Photo: Joy R. Absalon, USA TODAY Sports)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 The Baltimore Orioles had to go into extra innings to earn a victory that seemed assured far earlier in the night.Working overtime, however, did nothing to temper the enjoyment they derived from a 2-1 win over the Toronto Blue Jays on Saturday.BOX SCORE: Orioles 2, Blue Jays 1 (12 innings)Steve Lombardozzi tripled and scored on a single by David Lough in the 12th inning for the Orioles, who also got a key RBI from rookie Jonathan Schoop.Toronto trailed 1-0 with two outs in the ninth when Colby Rasmus hit a solo homer off Tommy Hunter on a 1-2 pitch. After nearly going around on a check swing one pitch earlier, Rasmus drove a 98 mph fastball into the right-field seats."He hit a pretty good fastball," Hunter said. "Sometimes you just tip your cap. He swung at a ball that was up. It was where I wanted. We talked about it afterward. One-run ballgame, you should probably throw the ball down and away instead of up, and he hit it."In the 12th, Lombardozzi hit a one-out drive to center off Todd Redmond (0-1) before Lough sliced an opposite-field liner to left. As soon as Lombardozzi crossed the plate, the Orioles sprinted from the dugout to embrace Lough, who scored Baltimore\'s other run five innings earlier."It looked like we were going to wrap it up there but unfortunately they got a run," Lough said. "But we just buckled down, stayed in the game, kept our heads up and we were able to come through with the hit."Zach Britton (2-0) got the win with two hitless innings of relief.It was the second straight low-scoring affair between two AL East foes known for their offensive prowess. On Friday night, Toronto scored two unearned runs in a 2-0 victory.In this one, neither starter allowed a run and neither got a victory for the effort. Bud Norris gave up five hits and three walks over seven innings for Baltimore and was poised to earn his first win of the season before Rasmus connected in the ninth."It didn\'t really do nothing for us," Rasmus lamented. "Most of the time when I face a guy who throws 98 (mph), I\'m going to look for the fastball hoping that guy\'s going to challenge."Drew Hutchison handcuffed the Orioles on four hits over six innings, walking two and striking out five."I have all the confidence in the world in our offense, just like the rest of our team does," the right-hander said. "It doesn\'t change my mindset one bit. My job is to go out and put up zeros."After Hutchison left, the Orioles struck in the seventh against right-hander Neil Wagner. Lough singled with two outs before Schoop, the No. 9 hitter, lined a 3-2 pitch into the alley in right-center for an RBI double.Evan Meek protected the lead in the eighth, but Hunter gave it away for his first blown save in four tries this season."You hopefully get a chance tomorrow," Hunter said. "The guys pulled it off, the team came through in the 12th. It\'s not a one-man show. There are a lot of guys, and I got picked up tonight."The game featured the first replay challenge at Camden Yards. In the fourth inning, Lombardozzi reached on a grounder when umpire Chris Conroy ruled that a throw from Hutchison pulled first baseman Edwin Encarnacion off the bag. Toronto manager John Gibbons challenged the call, and after a delay of 2 minutes, 38 seconds, the decision stood.Lough followed by hitting into an inning-ending double play.Both teams threatened in the third. Toronto put runners at the corners with one out before Maicer Izturis hit a short flyball and Jose Bautista struck out.In the bottom half, Hutchison struck out Chris Davis and Adam Jones after giving up successive one-out singles to Nick Markakis and Nelson Cruz.NOTES: Ubaldo Jimenez (0-2, 6.75 ERA) seeks his first win with the Orioles on Sunday. Mark Buehrle (2-0, 0.64) will pitch for Toronto, which is 0-3 in series finales. ... Toronto SS Jose Reyes (hamstring) ran the bases, said he felt "very good" and expects to start a rehabilitation assignment with Class-A Dunedin on Monday. If all goes well, he could join the Blue Jays next Friday in Cleveland. Also, closer Casey Janssen (oblique) will pitch in Dunedin on Monday or Tuesday, Gibbons said. ... Orioles SS J.J. Hardy returned from a five-game absence with back spasms. ... Toronto\'s Melky Cabrera has hit in 12 straight games, tied with Vernon Wells (2006) for the longest streak in franchise history to start a season. ... It was the first time this season that a Blue Jays starter was not involved in the decision.GALLERY: WALK-OFF WINSFacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInCelebrate good times: Baseball\'s walk-off wins\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. [('A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play - The New ...', '     Supported by    Baseball  A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play     Extra Bases  By                       TYLER KEPNER   APRIL 12, 2014     Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }        Chris Tillman pitches for the Baltimore Orioles, which means he can never assume the location of the infielders behind him.\xe2\x80\x9cI learned the hard way on a pop-up last year near the third-base line,\xe2\x80\x9d Tillman said. \xe2\x80\x9cI let the ball fall because I thought the third baseman was going to catch it \xe2\x80\x94 and there was nobody over there. It\xe2\x80\x99s on me, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned my lesson. I take a peek and see where my infielders are at.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Orioles used 595 shifts on balls in play last season, the most in the five seasons tracked by Baseball Info Solutions.Teams shifted about 2,400 times in 2010 and 2011, said Ben Jedlovec, a vice president for the company, and about 4,500 times in 2012. Last season, the total jumped to about 8,100, and teams are on pace for 13,000 shifts in 2014. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cClint Hurdle said nine of 10 balls up the middle used to be hits \xe2\x80\x94 and now, two of 10 are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Detroit Tigers General Manager Dave Dombrowski, referring to the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. \xe2\x80\x9cIt just shows how different it is.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Dombrowski\xe2\x80\x99s Tigers are using more shifts under their new manager, Brad Ausmus, but they are not alone. Entering the weekend, data showed that 23 of the 30 teams were on pace to deploy more shifts than they did last year.As teams compile more and more information on hitters\xe2\x80\x99 trends, managers can predict more accurately than ever where ground balls are most likely to go.\xe2\x80\x9cAs I told Brad when he joined us, we can supply you any statistical information you like, and it\xe2\x80\x99s up to you to do what you want with it,\xe2\x80\x9d Dombrowski said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to force it down players\xe2\x80\x99 throats, but he wants to show them why it\xe2\x80\x99s important.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Houston Astros entered the weekend on pace to use the most shifts this season, followed by the Yankees, the Milwaukee Brewers, the Orioles and the Chicago White Sox, who ranked 27th last year. Photo       Tampa Bay\xe2\x80\x99s Matt Moore, center, is the latest pitcher who may face Tommy John surgery.  Credit             Orlin Wagner/Associated Press           Bryan Price, the new manager of the Cincinnati Reds, said he watched a recent Yankees-Astros game and noticed the infielders shifting within the same at-bat. Price said that strategy seemed to disrupt the flow of the game, but he also acknowledged it could be smart.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In the new frontier of defensive positioning, teams are learning as they go.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re getting a lot of data, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve got some very creative minds out there that are looking at every aspect to enhance the quality of baseball,\xe2\x80\x9d Price said. \xe2\x80\x9cManagers are putting it in motion. There are some real pioneers out there that have taken the data and utilized it.\xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s that age-old thing: Every time you\xe2\x80\x99re burned by it, you remember that as opposed to the 10 other times it worked for you. And if you\xe2\x80\x99re talking about percentages, you\xe2\x80\x99re going to get beat. You\xe2\x80\x99re going to have Matt Adams cue one right down the left-field line on a squibber.\xe2\x80\x9dSure enough, just as Adams, of the St. Louis Cardinals, had beaten the Reds\xe2\x80\x99 shift, the Mets\xe2\x80\x99 Ike Davis did so last Sunday a couple of hours after Price spoke. The Reds won that game, though, and were ranked 10th in the majors in shifts, up from 13th last season.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Price, who was promoted from pitching coach to replace Dusty Baker, said the Reds made sure their pitchers agreed with the strategy before using it behind them. If a pitcher is more comfortable with a traditional infield alignment, he said, the Reds will go with that, no matter what the numbers suggest.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIn the end, this game\xe2\x80\x99s such a mental game,\xe2\x80\x9d Price said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf your heart\xe2\x80\x99s not in it, chances are performance is going to suffer.\xe2\x80\x9dA stray pop-up aside, Tillman said he had no problems pitching with the exaggerated shift behind him. The job of the pitcher, he said, is the same as always. Privacy Policy     \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s part of the game now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you make your pitches and execute the way you\xe2\x80\x99re supposed to, then I think it works out in your favor.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story   Elbow Trouble Starts Early  Matt Moore, an All-Star left-hander for the Tampa Bay Rays, last week became the latest pitcher to seriously injure his elbow, with reports indicating that he might have torn his ulnar collateral ligament.Moore may face Tommy John surgery, which would add him to the list of more than a dozen pitchers to have the procedure already this season. Photo       Milwaukee\xe2\x80\x99s Scooter Gennett (2) came up with his nickname based on his favorite Muppets character.  Credit             Jared Wickerham/Getty Images           Dr. James Andrews, the noted orthopedic surgeon, said the problem was not an anomaly but a troubling trend, mainly because of the popularity of youth travel teams and summer showcases. Last week, on MLB Network Radio, Andrews told Mike Ferrin and Jim Duquette that he had been \xe2\x80\x9cinundated\xe2\x80\x9d with high school and college pitchers needing elbow reconstruction.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThe big risk factor is year-round baseball,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrews, who saw Moore last week. \xe2\x80\x9cThese kids are not just throwing year round, they\xe2\x80\x99re competing year round, and they don\xe2\x80\x99t have any time for recovery. More is better. So year-round baseball is No. 1.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cNo. 2 is playing in more than one league at the same time, where rules don\xe2\x80\x99t count. And, of course, in showcases, where they\xe2\x80\x99re pitching for scouts, they try to overpitch and they get hurt.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Andrews also cited poor mechanics and pitchers throwing breaking balls at a young age. But the main problem, he emphasized, was that youngsters were throwing too hard too soon. Anything beyond 80 to 85 miles per hour, Andrews said, is more than a developing elbow ligament can handle.\xe2\x80\x9cThe radar gun\xe2\x80\x99s a problem,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Muppet in the Infield  The Milwaukee Brewers returned home Friday after a 6-0 trip to Boston and Philadelphia. The Brewers feasted on the Red Sox and the Phillies for 42 runs and 78 hits, with some familiar names \xe2\x80\x94 Ryan Braun, Carlos Gomez and Aramis Ramirez \xe2\x80\x94 leading the way.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Their second baseman is not as well known, but he might have the most fun name to say in baseball (at least, besides the mellifluous Arquimedes Caminero, who pitches for the Miami Marlins). He is Ryan Joseph Gennett, but everyone calls him Scooter. Gennett got the nickname when he was about 5, growing up in Cincinnati. As you might expect, there is a story behind it.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cOne day, I was in the car with my mom; she would always put on my seatbelt, and I would click it off,\xe2\x80\x9d Gennett said recently. \xe2\x80\x9cI was just a defiant kid, I always wanted attention, never really did what I was asked to do, just to see what would happen. So my mom actually took me to the police station to scare me a little bit.\xe2\x80\x9cThe police officer, I remember he asked me what my name was, and I thought if I told him my real name, I\xe2\x80\x99d get arrested. I was so young and scared. So I made up a name and said, \xe2\x80\x98Scooter.\xe2\x80\x99 That was the only name I really knew at the time. That was my favorite character. And I didn\xe2\x80\x99t answer to Ryan for about a year because I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d get in trouble and get arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Scooter is a character from \xe2\x80\x9cThe Muppet Show\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 round glasses, orange skin, no nose and a mop of orange hair. He is not a headliner like Kermit the Frog, but Gennett \xe2\x80\x94 himself more a complementary player than a superstar \xe2\x80\x94 connected with him while watching reruns after school.Gennett is not the first middle infielder to go by Scooter; Phil Rizzuto, the Hall of Fame shortstop and longtime Yankees broadcaster, was perhaps the original. Gennett said it sounded good as a baseball name, but he uses it everywhere.\xe2\x80\x9cSome of the teachers were like: \xe2\x80\x98What? I\xe2\x80\x99m not calling you that,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut eventually, they did. It started off as Ryan, but they ended up calling me Scooter. It just stuck.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on April 13, 2014, on Page SP2 of the New York edition with the headline: A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play .
