Related Coverage           Pitcher Brandon Finnegan Could Change Royals\xe2\x80\x99 Fortunes OCT. 1, 2014             ON BASEBALL   Royals Emerge Victorious and A's Leave With Another Postseason Loss OCT. 1, 2014              Former Yankee Russell Martin Helps Lead the Pirates OCT. 1, 2014                       ", 'www.nytimes.com'), ('ALDS 2014: Orioles vs. Tigers game one preview - Camden Chat', " ALDS Game 1Baltimore Orioles vs. Detroit Tigers5:37 p.m. on TBS, 1090 WBAL, ESPN Radio It feels like forever since we've seen Orioles baseball, doesn't it? Part of that is because they haven't played since Sunday, but also because they clinched way back on September 16th and have only been playing a watered down version of Orioles baseball since then. But tonight they are back at full strength, playing in their second ALDS in the past three seasons. We're all hoping that this year they won't stop at the ALDS, and to do that they need to beat some very good starting pitchers for the Detroit Tigers. Tonight's match up is Chris Tillman vs. Max Scherzer, with Scherzer being the pitcher on the Tigers staff is the most imposing.    Max Scherzer     GS IP ERA FIP WHIP BA/OBP/SLG   2014 33 220.1 3.15 2.85 1.175 .298/.234/.368   Career 198 1239.1 3.58 3.39 1.219 .242/.304/.391    You've probably heard about the Tigers defense and how it's one of their weaknesses. It's something that the Orioles can hopefully exploit in the series, but Scherzer already does his own part to neutralize it by getting over a quarter of his outs via the strikeout. It's hard to muff a ball that isn't put into play, and he's one of the best in the league at racking up K's. The Orioles didn't have the pleasure of facing him in the regular season, but they faced him twice in 2013 and in 14 innings against them he got 20 strikeouts. (He also gave up four runs, a 2.57 ERA, if you're interested in that kind of thing.) When teams do put the ball into play against him, they most frequently hit fly balls, though the difference between those and ground balls (41.6% to 36.7%) isn't very big. Over the past few years he has kept the fly balls in the ballpark pretty well. At first that seems like it might be because Comerica Park seems giant, but he's actually had more trouble with home runs at home.    As you can see by his 220 innings pitched this season, Scherzer is an inning eater. He pitched at least six innings in 29 of his 33 starts this year, and he's capable of throwing well over 100 pitches in an outing. That's also how Scherzer helps keep the team in the win column; he doesn't give the bullpen much time to blow it. It worked, too, as the Tigers won 24 of 33 games in which he started.    Lefties hit Scherzer better than righties, though not enough that you should get excited about it. 13 of his 18 home runs allowed were to lefties, and they slugged .382 opposed to .348 for righties. Wow, .382! That's about the same as Nick Markakis. So is there anything to be optimistic about regarding Scherzer? Although individual match ups don't generally mean much, there are a few Orioles who have done well against them in their careers. Adam Jones is 9-for-18 against Scherzer in his career with two doubles and a home run, and Nick Markakis has also had some success, 5-for-15 with two doubles and three walks. And then there is Nelson Cruz, who has slugged .800 over 26 career at-bats against him.    Chris Tillman     GS IP ERA FIP WHIP BA/OBP/SLG   2014 34 207.1 3.34 4.01 1.230 .238/.298/.373   Career 118 680.1 4.00 4.51 1.296 .248/.313/.419    Chris Tillman started the only game that the Orioles won this season against the Tigers, and it was a beauty. He pitched 8 1/3 innings with just five hits allowed. One of those hits was a solo home run by Torii Hunter, which accounted for the only run in the game. Tillman has actually had pretty good success against the Tigers in his career, pitching to a 3.58 ERA over six career starts and 37 2/3 innings. Tillman has pitched better at home this season, which could be good news for today's game. In 18 starts at home in 2014, Tillman he'd opponents to a hitting line of .224/.277/.329. He gave up 32 earned runs at home in 113 1/3 IP (2.52) at home, vs. 45 ER in 94 innings on the road (4.31).    Tillman hasn't faced any current Tiger enough times to really warrant mentioning, but I'm sure it doesn't surprise you that even in small sample size both Miguel Cabrera and Victor Martinez have had a lot of success.  ", 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('A Brief History Of Your Baltimore Orioles \\xab CBS Baltimore', ' BALTIMORE (WJZ) \xe2\x80\x94 Playoff push. The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 first postseason game is here! Mary Bubala reports it\xe2\x80\x99s bringing fans back to the glory days of Orioles baseball.  Sixty years of Orioles Magic is in the air at Camden Yards\xe2\x80\x93such a huge moment for our team and our town. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople have been biting at the bit for this for years to come. And today is the first step in the playoff process. And hopefully, by the end of October, we\xe2\x80\x99re sitting here with that world championship crown on our hats.\xe2\x80\x9d  From 1960 to 1997, the Orioles won more games than any other team in the league. Many believe a new winning era is taking hold. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the ball that made the last out when the Orioles clinched a spot in the playoffs.\xe2\x80\x9d At Sports Legends Museum, a new exhibit celebrates the O\xe2\x80\x99s American League East title from this year. Fans are coming to witness the team build a new history. \xe2\x80\x9cWe see a lot of fathers and sons or mothers and daughters come through. And the father will be telling the boy what this moment meant to him. And they start to cry.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThey have one of the most distinguished franchise histories of all the teams I would think.\xe2\x80\x9d But the last time the O\xe2\x80\x99s brought a World Series trophy home was 31 years ago.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 The Detroit Tigers and the Baltimore Orioles, two teams with proud postseason legacies dating back decades, had never faced each other in a playoff game until Thursday.They have 17 American League pennants between them (11 for Detroit), seven World Series titles (four for the Tigers) and numerous other playoff appearances, but none of those had come against the other \xe2\x80\x94 a notable hole in the fabric of postseason baseball.After witnessing the opening game of the teams\xe2\x80\x99 American League division series, it seems fair to say that the baseball world has not been missing much. Although the Tigers hit three home runs to the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 two, Detroit failed to execute plays when it mattered most and Baltimore took advantage, scoring eight runs in the eighth inning to turn a competitive game into a 12-3 rout at Camden Yards.Nelson Cruz, who hit 40 home runs in his first year with the Orioles, swatted a two-run homer in the first inning to start the power surge, and later hit a run-scoring single off Joba Chamberlain as the Orioles pulled away in the eighth, thanks in part to a fielding error by Andrew Romine, the Detroit shortstop. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The Orioles rapped out a dozen hits and went 6 for 11 with runners in scoring position as they chased the Tigers\xe2\x80\x99 starter, Max Scherzer, out of the game in the eighth, then punished the Detroit bullpen for seven more runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cOur style isn\xe2\x80\x99t conventional,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam Jones, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 center fielder. \xe2\x80\x9cWe hack, and sometimes we look like we have no idea what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing at the plate. But at some point in time it clicks.\xe2\x80\x9dThe clicking point Thursday came in the eighth. The Orioles sent twelve men to the plate, only two of whom faced Scherzer, and recorded six hits, including two doubles by Alejandro De Aza. With one out, De Aza doubled to right, and Chamberlain replaced Scherzer. Jones hit a playable ball to the left of Romine, who mishandled it, and DeAza scored. Romine chased the ball down in shallow left field and fired it home, too late to get the runner, then bent over in frustration. From there it got worse for the Tigers, especially when Rajai Davis committed another error. Photo       Alejandro De Aza doubled twice and scored in an eight-run eighth.  Credit             Patrick Semansky/Associated Press           \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a team effort,\xe2\x80\x9d Tigers Manager Brad Ausmus said. \xe2\x80\x9cIn baseball, a team effort is, if someone makes an error, you hope the pitcher picks them up. If a pitcher struggles, you hope the lineup picks him up. Tonight, we didn\xe2\x80\x99t get it done. Up until that point in the game, it was a pretty good game.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s home run in the first was his 15th in 35 postseason games, 14 of those homers coming when he was with the Texas Rangers. The Tigers responded in the top of the second inning against Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s starting pitcher, Chris Tillman, as Victor Martinez led off with a home run to right field, followed by another homer from J. D. Martinez.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  J. J. Hardy, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 shortstop, powered a changeup from Scherzer over the wall in center field to lead off the bottom of the seventh and give the Orioles an insurance run that seemed important. Miguel Cabrera answered with a bases-empty drive to right field off Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day with two outs in the eighth to pull Detroit within a run. Privacy Policy     Tillman retired 11 in a row after surrendering the two home runs in the second inning. But his pitch count grew high as the game went along. He needed 105 pitches to get through five innings, signaling the end of his night. Much of that workload was because of Ian Kinsler, the Tigers\xe2\x80\x99 leadoff batter, who saw 30 pitches in his first three at-bats, including 14 in his third-inning plate appearance.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Kinsler proved even more troublesome in the eighth, when he got a leadoff infield hit against O\xe2\x80\x99Day. But he tried to steal second base with Torii Hunter at the plate, and Hunter lined out to Hardy, who threw to first base to complete the double play.\xe2\x80\x9cIan was on his own there,\xe2\x80\x9d Ausmus said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a hit-and-run in that situation.\xe2\x80\x9dGame 2 is scheduled for 12:07 p.m. on Friday, a quick turnaround for a playoff series, and Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s Justin Verlander will pitch against Wei-Yin Chen. During his pregame news conference Thursday afternoon, Orioles Manager Buck Showalter asked a moderator why the game was set so early, and he was told it had to do with the markets \xe2\x80\x94 four games are scheduled Friday, two in the Eastern time zone and two in the West.\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about our market?\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter asked.He was concerned that the fans in Baltimore might be unable to get to a noon game and provide the kind of electric atmosphere that energized Camden Yards on Thursday. The fans, most of them wearing orange shirts, were also given small orange towels. When they waved them, the ballpark was saturated in an Oriole-themed monochrome.\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care how much you do this,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said after the game. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do feed off that. That was pretty special. Fun to watch. I felt like I wish I had a towel.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on October 3, 2014, on Page B12 of the New York edition with the headline: Teams\xe2\x80\x99 First Playoff Duel Turns Into Orioles Romp. Rob Carr/Getty Images/AFP (AFP Photo/Rob Carr)More- Baltimore pinch-hitter Delmon Young smacked a three-run double in the eighth inning Friday to give the Orioles a 7-6 victory over visiting Detroit in the Major League Baseball playoffs.The victory gave the Orioles a 2-0 lead in the best-of-five series. They can complete a sweep of the Tigers and advance to the American League Championship Series with a victory in game three Sunday at Detroit.Trailing 6-3 as they came to the plate in the bottom of the eighth inning, the Orioles began their comeback when Adam Jones was hit by Joba Chamberlain.Nelson Cruz followed with a single, Steve Pearce then singled to score Jones.Young, a former Tigers standout slugger, then went to the plate in place of Ryan Flaherty and smacked the first pitch he saw into left field, sending the base runners speeding for home plate.AFP ', 'www.yahoo.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium\xc2\xa0are only about 500 yards apart. But for the last three months, the ethical and moral distance separating the teams \xe2\x80\x94 and the sports they play \xe2\x80\x94 could\xc2\xa0not be greater.\xc2\xa0Indeed, the\xc2\xa0only common denominators between the teams are\xc2\xa0their success on the field and the fans who wildly cheer them.\xc2\xa0The Baltimore Orioles hold a 2-0 lead over the Detroit Tigers in their American League division series. The Ravens are 3-1 going into a pivotal game in Indianapolis against the Colts on Sunday.While local fans may bristle over the notion that there is a halo hovering over Camden Yards, where the Orioles play, and a cloud hanging over the Ravens\xe2\x80\x99 M&T Bank Stadium, many loyal Baltimore fans concede they understand how the rest of the country may have this view. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 success in Baltimore is not going to mitigate it in New York or Atlanta or anywhere else where they\xe2\x80\x99ve really painted the Ravens with such an ugly brush,\xe2\x80\x9d said Marc Sklar, the president and chief executive of Gian Marco, a high-end men\xe2\x80\x99s wear store in downtown Baltimore.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIn Baltimore, the Ravens could do no wrong before; the Ravens and Orioles will do no wrong now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the 67-year-old Sklar, a Baltimore native and a Ravens season-ticket holder.Not that the Orioles are purer than the driven snow. First baseman Chris Davis was suspended last month for testing positive for the stimulant Adderall.Major League Baseball announced the penalty, and the Orioles, without a fight, complied. The Ravens and the N.F.L. appeared to do all they could to protect the team and the league after learning of the existence of a graphic security tape showing Ray Rice knocking out his then-fianc\xc3\xa9e in an elevator.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Orioles Manager Buck Showalter alluded to the bond between Baltimore fans and their two major pro teams.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine a more supportive fan base,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a closeness and identification with this club. And our guys will be there at the Ravens games. They pull for them.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Johnny Unitas played quarterback here. Brooks and Frank Robinson and the fiery manager Earl Weaver were the faces of Orioles championship teams.Those were magical times, when athletes were part of the community, largely because they had to be. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s different now,\xe2\x80\x9d Sklar said. \xe2\x80\x9cJim Parker needed to own that bar,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, referring to the Colts Hall of Fame offensive lineman.In the glory days of the Baltimore Colts, players did not earn million-dollar salaries in professional sports. Today these guys earn obscene amounts of money. The reality is that those people were working-class people, just like Baltimore at that time.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Sklar\xe2\x80\x99s business partner, John Massey, said: \xe2\x80\x9cBaltimore was a factory town. It\xe2\x80\x99s no longer a factory town.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Professional athletes, no matter where they live, are no longer factory workers. And thanks in part to social media, they are not heroes anymore, either. Which raises a question: Is it wise for cities to attach their images to sports teams?Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake speaks for many residents for whom the Colts and the Orioles have been cornerstones of civic pride. \xe2\x80\x9cWhether it\xe2\x80\x99s wise or not, cities are going to do it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople look for something to root for.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  She added: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think you\xe2\x80\x99ll find any team that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t had its challenges. Ours have been more public than most, but they\xe2\x80\x99re the same challenges that many people have in their families. And we\xe2\x80\x99re looking to heal and to acknowledge when we\xe2\x80\x99re right and acknowledge when we\xe2\x80\x99re wrong, try to heal and move on.\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what families do.\xe2\x80\x9dRawlings-Blake, whose father, Howard P. Rawlings, was a respected Maryland legislator and political activist, is a lifelong fan of pro football in Baltimore and of Orioles baseball.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  She turned 14 on March 17, 1984, and 12 days later the Colts, who had been playing in Baltimore since 1953, left the city like thieves in the night and relocated to Indianapolis. \xe2\x80\x9cI still have PTSD over that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.What is heartening \xe2\x80\x94 or distressing, depending on your moral compass \xe2\x80\x94 is that player misdeeds have had little negative impact on Ravens attendance.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThe crowds have not diminished,\xe2\x80\x9d Massey said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe crowds have gotten bigger. I still see Ray Rice shirts on women and on men.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Since the mid-1970s, Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s Harborplace has been a model of urban revitalization. The Orioles and the Ravens have added tremendous value to the downtown area.  \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to minimize the current issues that have surfaced,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dr. Jay A. Perman, the president of the University of Maryland and the chairman of the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think people in Baltimore want to minimize it. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t see issues that need to be solved by the N.F.L. damaging the image of downtown Baltimore or Baltimore in general.\xe2\x80\x9dFrom a national perspective, Camden Yards is bathed in light and M&T Bank is wrapped in darkness. But viewed through the prism of a major metropolitan city fighting to survive, there is no light. There is no darkness. Two teams, a 10-minute walk apart, are closer than you think. Patrick Smith/Getty Images/AFP (AFP Photo/Patrick Smith)More- Baltimore pinch-hitter Delmon Young smacked a three-run double in the eighth inning Friday to give the Orioles a 7-6 victory over visiting Detroit in the Major League Baseball play-offs.The victory gave the Orioles a 2-0 lead in the best-of-five series. They'll try to complete a sweep of the Tigers on Sunday to advance to the American League Championship Series against either Anaheim or Kansas City.The Anaheim Angels were trying to bounce back from a game one defeat when they hosted the Royals later Friday.For the second game in a row, the Orioles secured victory with a scoring explosion in the penultimate inning.AFP ", 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: Forever Young - Birds Watcher', 'First off, after Delmon Young\xe2\x80\x99s heroics yesterday I tweeted that what we had seen in from the Baltimore Orioles and their fans over the past two games represented everything that was right with sports. We saw a city that was squarely behind it\xe2\x80\x99s team, perhaps in a manner that it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t done in years. And we not only saw a team that embraced the city back, but one that was determined to win despite any odds.Wei-Yin Chen pitched a couple of solid innings, but started to struggle the second time through the order. Chen\xe2\x80\x99s line: 3.2 IP, 7 H, 5 R, 0 BB, 3 K. Chen mowed Detroit down the first time through the order, but five consecutive hits in the fourth added to his early exits. And given Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s ability to hit southpaws, Chen probably knew going in that he\xe2\x80\x99d be on a short leash. However, he did have an early 2-0 lead on Nick Markakis\xe2\x80\x99 two-run homer in the last of the third. An instant replay review was inconclusive.Victor Martinez\xe2\x80\x99s RBI-single cut that lead to 2-1 in the fourth, however Martinez would later score on J.D. Martinez\xe2\x80\x99s two-run homer. Nick Castellanos would follow with a solo shot of his own, and Detroit suddenly had chased Chen and led the Orioles 5-2. However in a move that foreshadowed the ending, J.J. Hardy would keep the Orioles alive with an RBI-single to cut the lead to one.Kevin Gausman relieved Chen after his departure, and in his post season debut he did a great service to the Orioles and their bullpen by holding them over through the middle innings. The lone run he gave up was an RBI-double to Victor Martinez. However while at the time that looked to be an insurance run for Detroit (who led 6-3 at that point), it also came with a caveat. Famously slow runner Miguel Cabrera tried to score from second base as well, as he was gunned down at home plate. Adam Jones relayed the ball into Jonathan Schoop, who nailed Cabrera; that play swayed the momentum of the game, and perhaps the series.With one out in the last of the eighth Adam Jones was hit by a pitch, which sent an angry sentiment through the Camden faithful. Following a Nelson Cruz single, Steve Pearce\xe2\x80\x99s RBI-single scored Jones and cut Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s lead to 6-4. That brought J.J. Hardy to the plate, and with the game potentially hanging in the balance he walked on five pitches.  The passion at the yard was at a near frenzy by then, and the 48K plus in attendance could sense that something magic was about to happen as Buck Showalter looked at Delmon Young down the bench and said\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cgrab a bat.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Young\xe2\x80\x99s success in the post season is well documented, which is partially why Showalter asked him to pinch-hit for Ryan Flaherty. However I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure anyone in the crowd or in the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 dugout expected Young to get a first-pitch slider and for him to jump on it right away. In a moment that could only be called the inverse of the closing moments of\xc2\xa0Casey at the bat, Delmon Young sent a deep linerCourtesy of Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY Sportspast the left fielder J.D. Martinez all the way to the wall.It was obvious from the get-go that the game was going to be tied. However as Hardy rounded the bag third base coach Bobby Dickerson made perhaps his best decision of the season and sent him home. The throw home was on line, but as Hardy slid into home plate and kicked up a cloud of dirt, he was emphatically called safe by home plate umpire Scott Barry.Without being overly melodramatic, it was a scene out of a storybook. And quite frankly, it was legendary. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure that anyone who was even in the neighborhood of Camden Yards yesterday had ever heard it that loud. Delmon Young has been a role player and a pinch hitter for most of the season. But needless to say he cemented his name into Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 post season history with what he did yesterday. We won\xe2\x80\x99t know for sure where this moment stands in Orioles lore until it\xe2\x80\x99s put into the context of the full season. However needless to say, it was pretty special.Zach Britton somehow managed to tune out the Camden faithful with a cool head in the wake of that moment and closed out Detroit 1-2-3 in the ninth. The Orioles now head to Detroit with a 2-0 series lead, and they\xe2\x80\x99ll work out on the field at Comerica Park at 2 PM this afternoon. Game three of course will be at 3:45 PM on Sunday in Detroit. If the series has to go to game four, it would be at 12:07 PM on Monay \xe2\x80\x93 IF the Kansas City/Anaheim series is still on. (If that series has ended the O\xe2\x80\x99s would play at 1:37 PM.) If the series has to come back to Baltimore for game five, it would be at 5:37 PM. (If the Kansas City series is complete it would shift to 8:07 PM.)So bearing that in mind, I have a rare Saturday off \xe2\x80\x93 probably my first since prior to Spring Training. No better way to spend it than watching some college football, starting with the Terps at noon today!                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94  Ever since a cloud of midges swarmed Joba Chamberlain near the shores of Lake Erie, he has learned that he cannot control a hostile environment, only the pitches he throws within it. On Friday, it was not a swarm of insects that buzzed his ears, but a mob of howling fans, 48,058 strong, needling him with their sarcastic cheers.Once a feared and dominant reliever, Chamberlain was a pleasant sight for Orioles fans, and they let him know it.Chamberlain, once a Yankee but now a Detroit Tiger, was the first reliever out of the bullpen Thursday in an eighth inning that turned into an eight-run debacle. The fans at Camden Yards, with their little towels waving in a sea of orange overhead, were hoping for more of the same.What they got was even better. Baltimore was ahead when Chamberlain came in Thursday, but on Friday, he started the eighth with a three-run lead to protect. He recorded the first out, but he let the next three batters reach base, and the Orioles rode another Tigers bullpen collapse to a 7-6 victory in Game 2 of their American League division series. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      If the games lasted only seven innings, the Tigers would be in much better shape. Instead they have allowed the Orioles to score a combined 12 runs in the eighth innings of the first two games of the series.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Chamberlain was replaced by Joakim Soria, another culprit in the Game 1 meltdown. Soria walked J. J. Hardy to load the bases, and what happened next was almost predictable. Pinch-hitter Delmon Young, a former Tiger with a knack for postseason success, hit a bases-clearing double on a first-pitch slider from Soria.\xe2\x80\x9cThis one is on me,\xe2\x80\x9d Chamberlain said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I don\xe2\x80\x99t put us in that situation, Soria won\xe2\x80\x99t have to come into that situation, and obviously, this one\xe2\x80\x99s on me, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll wear it.\xe2\x80\x9dYoung has played in 34 postseason games \xe2\x80\x94 22 with the Tigers \xe2\x80\x94 and has nine home runs and 21 runs batted in.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve just been fortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d Young said. \xe2\x80\x9cI could just as easily hit a line drive to the left fielder for a sacrifice fly, and he has the opportunity to get out of the inning.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But it did not happen that way. Game 3 of the best-of-five series is Sunday in Detroit, where David Price will make his postseason debut for the Tigers against Miguel Gonzalez. If Detroit is fortunate enough to have the lead in that game, it is unclear whether Manager Brad Ausmus still has the confidence to turn to Chamberlain or Soria. Photo       Young\xe2\x80\x99s double completed Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s comeback.  Credit             Rob Carr/Getty Images           \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know that I necessarily have an answer for that,\xe2\x80\x9d Ausmus said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if we have a lead in the eighth inning on Sunday, we\xe2\x80\x99re going to have to find somebody.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Anibal Sanchez would be a good candidate. Normally a starter, he entered Friday\xe2\x80\x99s game after starter Justin Verlander was removed with a runner on base and no outs in the sixth.Sanchez threw two perfect innings, but he threw 30 pitches, and Ausmus said that was his limit, so in came Chamberlain. After Game 1, in which he did not record an out despite inducing two ground balls from the only two batters he faced, Chamberlain\xe2\x80\x99s earned run average this postseason was infinity. After Game 2, it is 108.00. Privacy Policy     The Tigers\xe2\x80\x99 bullpen, other than Sanchez, has allowed 10 earned runs and 8 hits in one and two-thirds innings for a 54.00 E.R.A.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Bullpen frailties are not new to the Tigers, whose championship hopes of the past have been derailed, in part, by the shortcomings of the former closer Jose Valverde. Since then, they brought in Joe Nathan to be the closer, but they have not even been able to get to him.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s certainly a little tough to swallow,\xe2\x80\x9d Ausmus said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you have a three-run lead going into the last couple of innings, you feel like you should get the job done. But we didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Tigers scored five times in the fourth, as J. D. Martinez hit a three-run homer and Nick Castellanos followed with another homer.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Then, in the top of the eighth, with Detroit leading, 5-3, and Torii Hunter on third and Miguel Cabrera on second, Victor Martinez doubled to left. Hunter scored, but the lumbering Cabrera was waved home and was thrown out at the plate for the first out of the inning. Detroit would not get that seventh run.In the bottom of the eighth, with the fans howling at him, Chamberlain got an out. But then, he hit Adam Jones with a pitch, and Nelson Cruz and Steve Pearce singled. As he came off the mound, Chamberlain, the victim of that midge attack seven years ago in Cleveland when he was a Yankee, heard the roar of the crowd as he walked into the clubhouse.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s something you expect,\xe2\x80\x9d he said of the fans. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x99s going to catch me off guard in this game, I can promise you that.\xe2\x80\x9dSoria walked Hardy, and then came Young, the most valuable player of the 2012 A.L.C.S. against the Yankees. Now, he is delivering the same big hits against Detroit.\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t sugarcoat it,\xe2\x80\x9d Hunter said. \xe2\x80\x9cOur backs are to the wall. Can\xe2\x80\x99t go no further backwards. It\xe2\x80\x99s not looking good. But we still have a pulse.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on October 4, 2014, on Page D5 of the New York edition with the headline: When Tigers Use Bullpen, Orioles Feel Relieved. Related Coverage          ORIOLES 12, TIGERS 3   Orioles Pummel Tigers in Teams\xe2\x80\x99 First Playoff Matchup OCT. 2, 2014              Dodgers\' Clayton Kershaw to Face Cardinals\' Adam Wainwright in a Division Series Opener OCT. 2, 2014             ROYALS 3, ANGELS 2   Royals Leap to Victory Against Angels in American League Opener OCT. 3, 2014                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Baseball-Major League Baseball roundup - Yahoo', 'Oct 4 (The Sports Xchange) - The Baltimore Orioles decided to start right-hander Bud Norris for Game Three of the American League Divisional Series on Sunday against the Detroit Tigers instead of righty Miguel Gonzalez.Baltimore planned to start Gonzalez, but announced Saturday that it will instead go with Norris. It is not clear why the club made the change.Norris, 29, was 15-8 with a 3.65 earned run average in 165 1/3 innings this regular season. He had a 2.08 ERA in five September starts. Sunday will mark Norris\' first career postseason start.Gonzalez, 30, was 10-9 with a 3.23 ERA in 159 innings this season. That includes a 2.09 ERA in his last 13 starts. However, he allowed seven runs in 3 1/3 innings in his only start against the Tigers. He allowed just one run over seven innings in his only career postseason start in 2012.The Orioles lead the best-of-five series 2-0 as it shifts to Detroit.- - -The scheduled starters for Game Three on Monday in San Francisco are Washington Nationals right-hander Doug Fister (16-6, 2.41 in the regular season) against Giants left-hander Madison Bumgarner (18-10, 2.98), who shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates in the wild-card game on Wednesday.The Giants set a MLB record with their ninth postseason win in a row with a 3-2 win over the Nationals in Game One on Friday."It has been a group of different guys that found a way to get it done. The streak is great. There is so much baseball ahead of us," said manager Bruce Bochy.The Giants outscored their opponents 47-9 in that stretch with five shutouts.- - -Wally Backman will not join the New York Mets\' coaching staff next season, according to the Bergen Record.Backman, a former Met and current manager of the club\'s Triple-A affiliate in Las Vegas, has been speculated to be promoted. Despite the Mets reassigning hitting coach Lamar Johnson and assistant hitting coach Luis Natera earlier this week, Backman reportedly will not join the coaching staff in 2015.Instead, the club offered Backman the chance to manage the Las Vegas 51s next season. However, it is not clear if he will return. (Editing by Gene Cherry) ', 'www.yahoo.com')]

[('Orioles sweep Tigers, advance to ALCS - USA TODAY', "Nelson Cruz hits a two-run home run in the sixth inning -- his second blast of the series.(Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREDETROIT --- Twenty-nine teams were scared off by Nelson Cruz's drug suspension and advancing age. The Baltimore Orioles were the 30th team and they are happy they took a chance on the 34-year-old designated hitter.BOX SCORE: Orioles 2, Tigers 1Cruz's two-run home run in the sixth inning off David Price snapped a scoreless tie and enabled the Baltimore Orioles to sweep their American League Division Series with a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers on Sunday at Comerica Park.Cruz's homer was enough support for the Orioles' pitchers as Bud Norris and a pair of relievers combined on a four-hitter.Closer Zach Britton provided an anxious moment in the ninth when he gave back-to-back doubles to Victor Martinez and J.D. Martinez to start the inning as the Tigers got within a run but he held on to get rookie pinch hitter Hernan Perez to ground into a game-ending double play.The Orioles advance to the American League Championship Series for the first time since 1997 and will face either the Kansas City Royals or Los Angeles Angels beginning Friday night. Baltimore also won a postseason series for the first time in 17 years when it beat the Seattle Mariners in four games in an ALDS.Manager Buck Showalter won a postseason for the first time in four tries during his 16-year career. He lost in the ALDS round in 1995 with the New York Yankees, 1999 with the Arizona Diamondbacks and 2012 with the Orioles.Cruz was suspended for 50 games last season in August, when he was playing for the Texas Rangers, for a violation of Major League Baseball's drug agreement related to the sport's investigation of the Biogenesis of America antiaging clinic.Despite hitting 27 home runs and driving in 76 runs in 109 games last season, Cruz remained on the free agent market until after the start of spring training. The Orioles signed him to a one-year contract for $8 million and he responded by leading the major leagues with 40 homers while batting .271 with 108 RBIs in 159 games as Baltimore won the AL East by 12 games over the New York Yankees.In the three ALDS games, Cruz went 6-for-12 (.500) with two homers and five RBIs.Cruz helped the Orioles overcome season-ending injuries to two of their stalwarts, catcher Matt Wieters (elbow) and third baseman Manny Machado. Baltimore is also without Chris Davis, who is serving a drug suspension that will stretch through the ALCS.Cruz's homer came after Adam Jones singled with one out and was a lined over the right-field fence.FacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInAL Division Series: Orioles vs. Tigers\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Eight of those have come against the Tigers, including six in the 2011 American League Championship Series when the Rangers beat Detroit.In his first career postseason game, Norris allowed just two hits in 6 1/3 scoreless innings with six strikeouts and two walks. Left-hander Andrew Miller followed with a 1 2/3 perfect innings before Britton survived the shaky ninth for his second save of the series.The Tigers acquired Price from the Tampa Bay Rays on July 31 in a blockbuster three-team trade that included the Seattle Mariners but he fell to 0-5 in five career postseason starts. He lasted eight innings and allowed the two runs and five hits while striking out six and walking two.Detroit made it to the ALCS each of the last three seasons and the World Series in 2012 but wound up having a winless postseason this year, its first since 1907 when the Tigers were swept by the Chicago Cubs in the World Series.CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ", 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: A Fitting End to the ALDS - Birds Watcher', 'Oct 5, 2014; Detroit, MI, USA; Baltimore Orioles players celebrate their win in the locker room after defeating the Detroit Tigers in game three of the 2014 ALDS baseball playoff game at Comerica Park. The Orioles move on to the ALCS with 2-1 win over the Tigers. Mandatory Credit: Rick Osentoski-USA TODAY SportsThis 2014 American League Division Series ended exactly the way it should have. The way it was meant to.The last three outs of the contest between the Baltimore Orioles and Detroit Tigers featured a resilient bullpen, expert managing, and strong defense \xe2\x80\x94 traits embodied by the 2014 Orioles all year \xe2\x80\x94 as the Orioles completed the three-game sweep, marking the first time since 1997 the team has advanced to the Championship Series.Much like the Orioles, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t without its flaws, but it was exciting, and it gave the fans what they want. As manager Buck Showalter often says, it was delayed, but not denied.Closer Zach Britton stared deep into a sea of suddenly awakened, white towel-waving Tiger fans that had finally sensed blood in the water from a pitching staff that had held them silent all game.The first two Tigers hitters Victor Martinez and J.D. Martinez just hit back-to-back doubles off of his usually ironclad 97 mph sinker to lead-off the ninth inning. The lead was cut in half, from 2-0 to a very tense 2-1 with a man in scoring position and no outs. Momentum was changing. It was the moment of doubt.Then, the Orioles closer showed his meddle.Britton stuck out catcher Bryan Holaday on a low-and-inside sinker gaining the inning\xe2\x80\x99s first out.After that, Buck Showalter made perhaps the best of his many great managerial moves this series. Showalter walked the last dangerous Tigers hitter, Nick Castellanos, unconventionally putting the winning run on first base with one out in the ninth inning.But as so many things have this season, it played out exactly as Showalter thought it might.Zach Britton, who induces ground balls at a 75 percent clip, got the double-play ball Showalter desired. Pinch hitter Hernan Perez, a man who saw six major league plate appearances all year, rolled the ball to third base, setting up the play that would send Baltimore into ecstasy.The 5-4-3 double play that ended the game appropriately began with Ryan Flaherty, who has sured-up a defensive weakness at third base the O\xe2\x80\x99s had felt since Manny Machado\xe2\x80\x99s injury in mid-August.Then the turn was made by Jonathan Schoop, who made one of the game\xe2\x80\x99s biggest plays in the bottom of the third inning. Schoop tagged out Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Don Kelly at second on a controversial fielder\xe2\x80\x99s choice where he held Kelly off the bag while retrieving a dropped J.J. Hardy feed before applying the tag.The throw went to now-everyday first baseman Steve Pearce, whose defense at a position he rarely played on the Orioles until this year has been both surprising and outstanding.Showalter\xe2\x80\x99s move wasn\xe2\x80\x99t about knowing the game. It was about knowing the guys on his team and his opponents\xe2\x80\x99 and putting his guys in a position to succeed. About sensing the moment, about reading body language, and capitalizing on an opportunity.Showalter refuses to be out-managed, and the Orioles refuse to be outplayed. The Orioles have responded to adversity several times already this postseason, and they don\xe2\x80\x99t give the impression that any challenge is too great. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: Past, present, and future in Baltimore', 'When I was a youg kid in the 1980\xe2\x80\x99s I spent a lot of Saturday mornings tailgating with my father and his college buddies outside of Byrd Stadium at the University of Maryland before football games. And in fact, we still all get together on occasion to renew that tradition at various sporting events. Nevertheless as great of a time as I had doing that, I always noticed a certain bitterness on the part of my father towards the entire \xe2\x80\x9cfootball establishment.\xe2\x80\x99My father grew up on the Baltimore Orioles and the Baltimore Colts. And as we know, the Colts were ripped away from Baltimore in March of 1984. If you ask my father now, he\xe2\x80\x99d tell you that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that big a deal to him and so forth. However in hearing his stories about the likes of Raymond Berry, Jimmy Orr, and of couse the great Johnny Unitas, as well as hearing stories from my uncles about how much all of them loved the Colts, I would submit that it was a big deal \xe2\x80\x93 at the time and now.Courtesy of Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsSo perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s somewhat fitting that on the same day the resurrgent Orioles, long thought to be dead and gone, are going for a sweep in the ALDS, Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s Ravens are in Indianapolis playing none other than the Colts. Let\xe2\x80\x99s not forget that as much as some folks wanted the entire public to forget about the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 storied past for the better part of a generation, it was always there. The Orioles of course have won three World Series\xe2\x80\x99 to date, and between 1966-82 were the winningest organization in baseball. Throughout that time numerous hall of famers came through the dugout at Memorial Stadium, from Earl Weaver, Frank Robinson, Jim Palmer, Eddie Murray, Cal Ripken Jr., and of course the greatest third baseman of all time, Brooks Robinson.However as we also know, following two seasons (1996-\xe2\x80\x9997) of dominant baseball, the O\xe2\x80\x99s fell on hard times. And it was no coincidence that the time period was the same as New York and Boston being dominant. Literally, there was nothing that the Orioles could do right; whether it was hiring coaches, keeping players out of trouble, executing double-plays, or even having guys stay on their feet on the base paths. If there was a will to have something go wrong, there was a way. Again as we know, this futility seemed to be all the more loud when the aforementioned AL East rivals would come to Camden Yards \xe2\x80\x93 along with their fans. The Orioles would suffer the shame of hearing their follies cheered in their own ballpark by rival fans.Similarly as I said above, Baltimore football fans suffered when the Colts left. The warm relationship that the fans have with the teams was on display in the first two games of the ALDS, and that was also true of the Colts. It was during Colt games that Memorial Stadium got the nickname\xc2\xa0The World\xe2\x80\x99s Largest Outdoor Insane Asylumn.\xc2\xa0We all by now know the story of the Baltimore Colt Marching Band, and how they kept the fire buring for the city to get a team to come back. (And for the record, their act of playing the Colts\xe2\x80\x99 fight song on the State House steps in order to secure funding for new stadiums might have saved the Orioles from moving as well.) That in and of itself shows the love that this community has for it\xe2\x80\x99s teams.From Unitas, Berry, Robinson (both of them), Murray, Ripken, (Bert) Jones, to Lewis, Flacco, (Adam) Jones, Cruz, Markakis, and many more, Baltimore has seen it\xe2\x80\x99s share of great athletes over the years. So again, perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s fitting that today we\xe2\x80\x99ll see the past, present, and hopefully the future of the city\xe2\x80\x99s sports teams all coming together like a bowl of crab soup. The football team will take on the old football team, while the once maligned and spat on baseball team will attempt to take it\xe2\x80\x99s return to glory a step further.Incidentally, there\xe2\x80\x99s synergy between the Ravens and Orioles, just as there was between the Colts and the Orioles years ago. That wasn\xe2\x80\x99t always the case. So while one could argue that it\xe2\x80\x99s in fact Detroit who\xe2\x80\x99s hosting the doubleheader with the Lions and then the Tigers, I would submit that that city of Baltimore is getting a much more unique doubleheader today. Sports certainly has had a checkered history in Baltimore at times, however that\xe2\x80\x99s what makes today so special. The Ravens\xe2\x80\x99 two Super Bowls were sweeter because the city had lost NFL football once. And this season has been special to Orioles fans because of the 14 years of losing.And in both of those stories there lies a lesson in grit, bravado, and never giving up. That\xe2\x80\x99s a lesson that can be taught by the Baltimore Colt Band (now the Marching Ravens), as well as by the very concept of the\xc2\xa0Fighting Showalters. Whether the Ravens and Orioles win or lose today is irrelevant; the battle\xe2\x80\x99s already been won, and by the city of Baltimore at that. ', 'birdswatcher.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  DETROIT \xe2\x80\x94  As the Baltimore Orioles hugged and jumped on the infield grass in celebration, Buck Showalter stood calmly in the dugout, his arms folded and a proud smile crossing his face as he watched the proceedings.Three times before his teams had reached the playoffs, losing their opening series each time. Twice, he had the misfortune of guiding a club to the divisional round of the playoffs only to see a different manager take it to a World Series title the year after he left.The Yankees, who lost a division series under Showalter in 1995, won the 1996 championship under Joe Torre. The Arizona Diamondbacks, who lost a division series under Showalter in 1999 and fired him after an 85-77 season in 2000, captured a title in 2001 with Bob Brenly.All Showalter could do was accept that he had played some role in the teams\xe2\x80\x99 development, even if he could not celebrate with them. Now, though, Showalter, in his fifth year with the Orioles and his 16th as a big-league manager, is finally going to a league championship series, having earned his first playoff series win with a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers. The Orioles will play the Kansas City Royals. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter deadpanned. \xe2\x80\x9cI won one in Albany.\xe2\x80\x9dA baseball lifer, Showalter began managing in the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 minor league system in 1985, and, yes, during his time with a Class AA team in Albany, Baseball America named him its minor league manager of the year, in 1989.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  That distinction cannot compare with what happened Sunday, when Showalter led the Orioles to a win in Game 3 of an American League division series, completing a sweep and returning the team to the A.L. Championship Series for the first time since 1997.Bud Norris pitched the game of his life, and Nelson Cruz hit a two-run homer to lead the way. But the victory was due in no small part to Showalter\xe2\x80\x99s guidance.With some of his stars out because of injuries and a suspension, Showalter conjured solid performances from a cast of lesser-known players and made brilliant tactical moves along the way, especially in the playoffs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In Game 2, he waited for the right moment to use Delmon Young as a pinch-hitter, and Young\xe2\x80\x99s bases-clearing double proved decisive. On Sunday, he called on Norris, originally scheduled to start Game 4, and Norris produced a gem, holding the Tigers to two hits through six and a third scoreless innings.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Still, the game came down to one bold move by Showalter in the ninth inning that went against all baseball convention: He put the potential winning run on base with an intentional walk. Photo       Jonathan Schoop after Baltimore\'s win over Detroit.  Credit             Rick Osentoski/Reuters           Then again, this is the same manager who once intentionally walked Barry Bonds with the bases loaded and lived to tell about it.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cBuck has been doing this a long time,\xe2\x80\x9d Tigers Manager Brad Ausmus said of the decision. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think he could do anything that would shock me.\xe2\x80\x9dWith the Orioles leading, 2-0, entering the ninth, Tigers designated hitter Victor Martinez doubled off Zach Britton, and J. D. Martinez followed with another double to make the score 2-1. Privacy Policy     Britton then struck out Bryan Holaday, bringing up Nick Castellanos with one out.Showalter went to the mound and made the call: Britton would walk Castellanos to set up a potential double play and take his chances against whatever the Tigers had on their bench (which was not much).
