                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94  Jarrod Dyson got a new haircut for the postseason. Dyson, the Kansas City Royals\xe2\x80\x99 speedy reserve outfielder, had the outline of a four-letter word, in all capitals, buzzed just above his right ear: ZOOM, it says.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do\xc2\xa0tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d Dyson said at Camden Yards\xc2\xa0on Thursday.\xc2\xa0He is probably not kidding. The Royals had the most stolen bases in the major leagues this season. The Baltimore Orioles, their opponent in the American League Championship Series, had the fewest. The Orioles, however, hit the most home runs in the majors. The Royals \xe2\x80\x94 you guessed it \xe2\x80\x94 hit the fewest.Contrasts don\xe2\x80\x99t get starker than that, but these franchises have one big thing in common: a decades-long yearning for a championship. The Royals have the most losses in the A.L. since 2000, and the Orioles have the second most. Both have built patiently for this moment, for a chance at their first World Series appearance since the 1980s.While the National League Championship Series features the familiar St. Louis Cardinals and San Francisco Giants \xe2\x80\x94 who have combined to win the last four N.L. pennants \xe2\x80\x94 the Orioles have not reached the World Series since 1983, and the Royals since 1985. Photo       Mike Moustakas, right, and Lorenzo Cain of the Royals, who led the major leagues in stolen bases.  Credit             Lon Horwedel/FRE170538, via Associated Press           \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s great for baseball, just because you get some new teams in there, and you see the excitement in the crowds,\xe2\x80\x9d the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 Billy Butler said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think fans all around baseball are excited to see some new teams.\xe2\x80\x9d Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Both teams swept their division series, the Royals over the Los Angeles Angels, who led the majors in victories and runs, and the Orioles over the Detroit Tigers, who started three former Cy Young Award winners.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Royals hit only .198 against the Angels but found their power when they most needed it, with two homers apiece from Eric Hosmer and Mike Moustakas. Each hit a go-ahead, 11th-inning home run on the road against the Angels and another homer in the Game 3 clincher at Kauffman Stadium.Anything can happen in a short series, of course, and perhaps the Royals will take advantage of the cozy dimensions at Camden Yards and hit more home runs. Whether or not that happens, though, they know they will run. Photo       The Orioles agreed to a three-year contract extension with J.J. Hardy, a top fielding and home-run-hitting shortstop.  Credit             Nick Wass/Associated Press           \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s our game plan; that\xe2\x80\x99s the strength of our ball club,\xe2\x80\x9d Hosmer said. \xe2\x80\x9cTeams know what we\xe2\x80\x99re going to do. They know we\xe2\x80\x99re going to steal. They know we\xe2\x80\x99re aggressive, and it takes a perfect throw to get our guys.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  With Matt Wieters lost to Tommy John surgery, that task falls to the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 catching tandem of Nick Hundley and Caleb Joseph, a rookie who caught 40 percent of potential base stealers, the best mark in the A.L. Hundley is likely to catch Game 1 for Chris Tillman, who has allowed just two stolen bases the last two seasons, and Joseph said the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 pitchers are quick to the plate, whatever they throw.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve done such a good job at their times being fairly consistent with both the fastball and off-speed pitches, so there\xe2\x80\x99s not a huge variation,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph said. \xe2\x80\x9cMost guys start getting slower times with the off-speed pitches, but our guys are really close. So you\xe2\x80\x99re not as pressured to call fastballs. Ultimately, if you continue to get the hitter out, then it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter how many times he steals.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 pitchers had the A.L.\xe2\x80\x99s third-best E.R.A. this season, at 3.44, and the staff got even better on\xc2\xa0July 31\xc2\xa0with a trade for the left-handed reliever Andrew Miller. In 231/3 innings for Baltimore, including the postseason, Miller has 37 strikeouts and a 1.16 E.R.A. Photo       Thanks to late-inning relievers including Kelvin Herrera, the Royals are the second team (after the 1907 Cubs) with three pitchers with at least 60 innings and an E.R.A. lower than 1.50.  Credit             Charlie Riedel/Associated Press           Manager Buck Showalter deployed Miller twice in the division series, each times for five outs, and tends to be more unpredictable in bullpen usage, responding to the moment rather than adhering to strict roles. Ned Yost, the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 manager, tends to manage more traditionally, offering another contrast in a series with many of them \xe2\x80\x94 against a common backdrop.\xe2\x80\x9cBoth franchises are starving for a winner,\xe2\x80\x9d the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Adam Jones said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got two franchises that haven\xe2\x80\x99t been in that limelight. Now they\xe2\x80\x99re in it. Let\xe2\x80\x99s see what can happen.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  EXTENSION FOR HARDY The Orioles took shortstop J. J. Hardy off the free-agent market Thursday by reaching a three-year contract extension, widely reported to be worth $40 million, with an option for 2018. Hardy, who could have been an option for the Yankees as they seek a replacement for Derek Jeter, has hit 86 homers in the last four seasons, most among major league shortstops, while winning two Gold Gloves.HISTORIC DOMINANCE The Royals\xe2\x80\x99 late-inning bullpen triumvirate of Kelvin Herrera, Wade Davis and Greg Holland was overwhelmingly effective this season, each with an earned run average below 1.50. According to Baseball Prospectus, the Royals are only the second team to have three pitchers with at least 60 innings and an E.R.A. under 1.50. The other? The 1907 Chicago Cubs, who used just eight pitchers all season and had little use for a bullpen, tossing 114 complete games. Photo       Moe Drabowsky, pictured in the 1966 World Series, pitched for both Baltimore and Kansas City.  Credit             Associated Press           DAVIS MUST WAIT The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Chris Davis is featured prominently in a billboard above the center-field seats at Camden Yards, but that is the only place fans may find him in the A.L.C.S. Davis\xe2\x80\x99s 25-game suspension for taking Adderall without a therapeutic-use exemption is set to expire after the first five games of this series, but the Orioles did not put him on their active roster. Buck Showalter said they did not want to play with a 24-man roster until Davis returned. Davis, an All-Star first baseman last season who now plays third, took grounders and batting practice during Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s workout.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  NEW DADS Two of the more important players in the A.L.C.S. have been busy since their teams clinched the division series. Orioles closer Zach Britton took a red-eye from California, arriving here Thursday after the birth of his son, Zander. Royals center fielder Lorenzo Cain flew in from Oklahoma City after the birth of his son, Cameron. \xe2\x80\x9cI was crying like a big baby,\xe2\x80\x9d Cain said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad I was able to make it.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  GOOD COMPANY Nelson Cruz and Frank Robinson both have 149 career plate appearances in the postseason. Cruz, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 designated hitter, has 16 home runs, and Robinson, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Hall of Famer, had 10. Robinson had a .532 slugging percentage in the postseason, almost identical to his regular-season mark. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s career postseason slugging percentage is .710, more than 200 points above his regular-season figure.SPENDING IN MODERATION The Orioles ranked 15th in the majors in opening-day payroll, at roughly $107 million, while the Royals ranked 19th, at about $92 million. Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s franchise record is a six-year, $85.5 million contract for outfielder Adam Jones, who is signed through 2018. The Royals\xe2\x80\x99 record guarantee is $55 million, for outfielder Mike Sweeney after the 2002 season and for pitcher Gil Meche, who retired before he could finish the deal in 2011.  COMMON ALUMNI Moe Drabowsky was the winning pitcher in the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 first World Series game in 1966, blanking the Dodgers for six and two-thirds innings in relief. Three years later, on April 8, 1969, Drabowsky won the first game in the history of the Royals, working a scoreless 12th inning in a 4-3 victory over Minnesota. That game was started by another expansion draft choice, Wally Bunker \xe2\x80\x94 another Orioles hero in that 1966 World Series. Bunker pitched a shutout in Game 3, the first World Series game held in Baltimore. The first batter in Royals\xe2\x80\x99 history, Lou Piniella (he doubled), started his career with four games for the Orioles in 1964. Other notables to play for both teams include Mike Boddicker, who earned the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 first victory in the 1983 World Series; Gregg Olson, who won the 1989 A.L. Rookie of the Year award as the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 closer; and Royals starter Jeremy Guthrie, who pitched five seasons for Baltimore, twice leading the league in losses.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  PLAYOFF HISTORY The Orioles or the Royals played in the A.L.C.S. 10 times in 13 seasons from 1973 to 1985, the years of Jim Palmer, George Brett and other colorful stars. Yet not once did the teams meet for the pennant. That changes on Friday at 8 p.m. at Camden Yards.  A version of this article appears in print on October 10, 2014, on Page B10 of the New York edition with the headline: Lightning vs. Thunder.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 Amid a sea of waving orange towels and unwavering hope, a new era of baseball arrived at Camden Yards on Friday.The Baltimore Orioles and the Kansas City Royals, two cornerstones of the American League, had never played each other in the postseason, despite distinct periods of success in both towns, especially in the 1970s.In the first 17 years after the playoff format was introduced in 1969, one or the other team was in the American League Championship Series in all but four of those years, though neither had been to the Championship Series in a very long time.So, on a cool night that provided a fitting backdrop for a playoff game, the teams finally engaged in a battle worthy of the wait. The Royals took an early four-run lead, and the Orioles fought back to even the score after six innings. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      But in the top of the 10th Alex Gordon hit a leadoff home run off Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day and Mike Moustakas added a two-run shot off Brian Matusz. The suspense wasn\xe2\x80\x99t over yet, though. The Orioles scored a run in the bottom of the 10th and had two runners on base for the final at-bat. But the Royals held on for an 8-6 victory in Game 1 of the A.L.C.S., a contest so entertaining, even the losers could appreciate it.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a great baseball game,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles center fielder Adam Jones said. \xe2\x80\x9cObviously, you want to come out on top, but it was a great game. Both teams kept fighting.\xe2\x80\x9dThe surging Royals, who won their first two games of the division series with extra-inning home runs, became the first team to hit three go-ahead home runs in extra innings in a single postseason. The Royals, who hit the fewest home runs in baseball during the 162-game regular season with 95, have seven in five postseason games.It was also their fourth extra-inning win in those games, starting with their wild-card victory over the Oakland Athletics.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI like playing nine innings,\xe2\x80\x9d Moustakas said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if it takes 10 or 11 to get a win, everybody in this clubhouse is all for it.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Game 2 is Saturday afternoon, with Yordano Ventura pitching for the Royals against Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s Bud Norris, who will seek to quiet the Royals recent display of power.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Gordon\xe2\x80\x99s homer, which came on an 87-mile-per-hour fastball from O\xe2\x80\x99Day, helped make up for the fact that the Royals had the bases loaded with nobody out in the top of the ninth and failed to score. Zach Britton, the Orioles reliever, walked three straight batters, throwing 12 consecutive balls before righting himself.He got Eric Hosmer to hit into a fielder\xe2\x80\x99s choice, and O\xe2\x80\x99Day, the side-arming right-hander, replaced Britton and he got Billy Butler to hit into a double play as the announced crowd of 47,124 roared its approval, at least for a short while.O\xe2\x80\x99Day also felt good walking into the dugout after that, and coming back out for the 10th. But his fortunes changed quickly, as Gordon struck on his third pitch, a fat 1-1 offering right over the plate. Privacy Policy     \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the highs and lows of playoff baseball,\xe2\x80\x9d O\xe2\x80\x99Day said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou come in the inning before and get out of a situation you don\xe2\x80\x99t expect to get out of. And the inning after that, it\xe2\x80\x99s like you\xe2\x80\x99re throwing B.P. and you give up a homer.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Both teams carried momentum into the series, with neither having lost a postseason game entering this series. The Orioles, who last competed at this stage for the pennant in 1997, swept the Detroit Tigers in the divisional round. The Royals, whose last appearance in the playoffs came in 1985, the year they won the World Series, did the same to the Los Angeles Angels.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Anticipation for this unprecedented matchup began with tens of thousands of Orioles fans dressed in black and orange, swarming the streets around the stadium for hours in advance, and then bringing the stadium to life with their energetic cheers once the game began.A light rain started falling in the middle innings, but the game went on, with Chris Tillman, the starting pitcher of the Orioles, facing the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 James Shields.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Royals were the first to score as Alcides Escobar homered to left field off Tillman in the third inning. Kansas City would score three more times in the inning, even after Tillman came within inches of ending the inning with the bases loaded and only one run in.With one out, Nori Aoki singled to left field and Lorenzo Cain walked. Tillman struck out Hosmer looking, but Billy Butler singled to load the bases. The next batter, Gordon, worked a 2-2 count against Tillman, setting the stage for two more critical pitches in the at-bat.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The next pitch was a brilliantly executed backdoor curve that was right on the outer edge of the strike zone, nearly impossible for Gordon to drive. So he did not swing, and the plate umpire, Tim Timmons, gave him the benefit of the doubt, calling a ball to bring the count full.Gordon then lofted a fastball into right field for a double as all three runners scored, and Gordon advanced to third on an error by Schoop as the Royals grabbed a 4-0 lead.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Orioles added a run in the bottom of the inning when Nick Markakis doubled off Shields and scored on a single by Adam Jones, and chipped more off the deficit in the bottom of the fifth. Trailing by 5-1, Nelson Cruz doubled home a run and Ryan Flaherty hit a two-run single to make it 5-4.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Kansas City retained the lead, but the Orioles went on to wipe it out an inning later against the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 bullpen. Jonathan Schoop walked against Brandon Finnegan and went to second on a single by Markakis, but was lucky not to be picked off. With Alejandro De Aza at the plate, Royals catcher Salvador Perez, who has a terrific arm, saw Schoop stray too far off the base and fired down to second. Schoop knew he would have been out there, so he broke for third, and Escobar\xe2\x80\x99s relay to Moustakas was wild. Schoop was safe at third.De Aza then placed a little flare perfectly over Finnegan\xe2\x80\x99s head, in front of Escobar, who dove but could not catch the ball. Everyone was safe, and Schoop slid home to finally even the score, 5-5, with more drama to come.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s deflating for a team,\xe2\x80\x9d Hosmer said of the Baltimore comeback. \xe2\x80\x9cBut Gordo got that swing, shifted the energy, and shifted the momentum back to our side.\xe2\x80\x9d   Correction: October 14, 2014           An article on Saturday about Game 1 of the American League Championship Series referred incorrectly to the history of the Baltimore Orioles. While the Kansas City Royals were one of the \xe2\x80\x9ccornerstones of early American League expansion,\xe2\x80\x9d the Orioles were not. (The franchise was the St. Louis Browns before moving to Baltimore for the 1954 season.) Preview: Kansas City Royals vs. Baltimore Orioles OCT. 9, 2014                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Opening act suggests Royals-Orioles ALCS will be an epic', 'Mike Moustakas and Salvador Perez celebrate Moustakas\' two-run homer that sealed the Royals\' 10-inning Game 1 win.(Photo: H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Sports)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 Get used to this.Six innings of baseball and enjoyment then \xe2\x80\xa6 especially if you\'re invested in who wins \xe2\x80\xa6 a tense game of high-stakes chess in an atmosphere more fit for Mardi Gras.The Kansas City Royals finally broke from the anticipated formula to beat the Baltimore Orioles 8-6 in 10 innings Friday in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series.Pace of game? Pace of heartbeats will be the bigger concern if those 4 \xc2\xbd hours are merely a taste of a seven-game feast.Advantage Kansas City after Alex Gordon and Mike Moustakas decided the game with the Royals\' new-found post-season magic \xe2\x80\x93 extra-inning homers.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } Flair for dramatics: Royals take 1-0 ALCS lead with late HRsBoth teams tout their relief pitching with good reason. Baltimore\'s blinked. Kansas City\'s \xe2\x80\x94 more specifically premier set-up man Wade Davis \xe2\x80\x94 provided the crucial turn in a game of alternating momentum swings that only became more rapid-fire as the game went deeper into the drizzly night.The touted Royals\' speed vs. Orioles\' power matchup was a wash. The bullpen battle wasn\'t. And Kansas City showed the added advantage that it can also do what Baltimore does best."Everybody\'s doubting our power," says Jarrod Dyson, who in his familiar late-inning pinch-running role found himself caught stealing, only the team\'s second in 14 tries this postseason. "It\'s good to have that speed in our back pocket. It\'s always there. But, last I checked, we\'ve hit a lot of bombs in the postseason."The Royals have won all three of their road playoff games, all in extra innings, all on home runs \xe2\x80\x94 the first team ever to win three such games in the same postseason.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } Alex Gordon leading Royals: \'He can do it all\'It\'s the Orioles who were first in the majors in home runs and last in stolen bases, precisely the opposite of the Royals. Yet, Kansas City had the game\'s only homers, Baltimore\'s the only two steals. Go figure.And if there ever seemed a moment when Baltimore was ready to deliver the quick-strike dagger it was in the bottom of the ninth after the Royals couldn\'t break a 5-5 tie despite loading the bases with no outs.But Wade Davis, pitching a second inning of relief for the first time since May 29, struck out Alejandro de Aza, Adam Jones and Nelson Cruz in order."That really shifted momentum," says Royals first baseman Eric Hosmer. "It was all on their side and Wade went in there and shut the door."Davis knew he would pitch the ninth if the game were tied, but when Zach Britton walked the first three batters, closer Greg Holland seemed a cinch to take over with a lead.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } AL Championship Series: Breaking down Orioles vs. RoyalsNot so, with Britton getting Hosmer to hit into a force out at home and Darren O\'Day taking over and inducing a double play from Billy Butler.Davis had to regroup."I was rooting as hard anyone was," he said. "But I had to keep running up to the clubhouse to keep loose, too."Davis\' second inning was perfect. O\'Day\'s wasn\'tGordon\'s winner into right field led off the 10th inning and gave his three hits and four RBI. Moustakas hit a two-run shot later in the inning off Brian Matusz.So, for one night at least, Kansas City showed it can also do what Baltimore does best. There\'s not much evidence the Orioles are going to turn into base path burners. Their two stolen bases Friday came when Jonathan Schoop was picked off second by catcher Salvador Perez but headed for third and was safe then the relay hit him on the back of the head. Nick Markakis trailed along from first on the play for the other steal.That set up the run that tied the game 5-5 in the sixth, merely setting up the main event.Both teams got here playing the underdog card, the old Little Engine That Could theme.But from the seventh inning on, they simply CAN.Even for the managers, it\'s more a matter of maneuvering to that point because they have the scripts down pat from there.Friday\'s six-inning prequel was a sometimes spectacular, sometimes shoddy but always intriguing mix of fundamentals and flaws, sliding catches and base-running blunders, big hits and bigger rallies.A dominant starting pitcher will be a luxury in this series \xe2\x80\x93 and neither team had one in No. 1\'s James Shields and Chris Tillman on Friday.The tie at the point they both were gone had enough twists to keep the wild Camden Yards crowd from even noticing the intermittent rain \xe2\x80\x94 10 runs, 25 base runners, the home team coming back from four runs down.Once the showdown began in earnest, the Orioles had the upper hand more often.The Royals are looking for that one opportunity, get a foot in the door and two feet on the bases \xe2\x80\x94 and just run. The Orioles didn\'t let them.Nori Aoki walked to lead off the Royals seventh against Kevin Gausman. Dyson, the one who spent Thursday\'s media sessions reminding everyone that the Royals are here to run and pretty much daring the Orioles to stop them, pich-ran.Track meet?Gausman accepted the challenge, throwing to first base five times with Lorenzo Cain at the plate. One throw nearly caught Dyson leaning the wrong way, the next one was so close that Orioles manager Buck Showalter came onto the field considering \xe2\x80\x93 but eventually eschewing \xe2\x80\x93 a replay challenge.Dyson finally went \xe2\x80\x93 the first time all night Kansas City even attempted a stolen base. Nick Hundley\'s throw got him, only the second time in 14 tries this postseason that a Royals runner was out trying to steal.Britton walked Alcides Escobar to lead off the ninth. Escobar created perhaps the most stunning development of the night when he produce the game\'s first run with a homer \xe2\x80\x93 he had three in 620 plate appearances during the regular season.But the Royals were plotting their more conventional method of winning. But Britton, who hadn\'t walked more than one batter in a game all season, loaded the bases on walks, including 12 pitches in a row out of the zone.But the bullpen made it an easy-chair finish for Yost despite the letdown in the top of the ninth. Once he got into his late-inning triumvirate, everything else fell into place. Kelvin Herrera got five consecutive outs to get Kansas City through the seven. Davis was perfect in the eighth and ninth.Holland\'s 10th could have been anti-climactic but after two outs, he allowed three consecutive base runners and had to get potential winning run Markakis to ground out to finish the game.Fitting because it\'s not likely this series will provide many anti-climactic moments.GALLERY: Orioles, Royals clash in ALCS     .oembed-asset-photo-image {         width: 100%;     } CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ("Orioles on ropes after sluggers, starters can't go long", 'Orioles closer Zach Britton walks off the mound in the ninth inning.(Photo: H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Sports)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE - Reset? Try regroup, too.The Baltimore Orioles knew they were headed to a different sort of baseball beginning Monday in Kansas City. What they desperately wanted to \xe2\x80\x93 and couldn\'t \xe2\x80\x93 avoid was facing a 2-0 deficit in the American League Championship Series.Finally, a trademark small-ball rally from the Royals in the ninth inning that produced two runs and a 6-4 victory, a fourth consecutive postseason road victory, a perfect 6-0 overall and the somber realization for the Orioles that their next home game could be in April.Alcides Escobar slashed a double over first base with one out in the ninth, scoring pinch-runner Terrance Gore to break the tie and it all goes west from there.The narrative for this series has been about the contrast in styles.Yet, neither team has thrived on what it does best.The Orioles have shut down the Kansas City running game. The Royals have pretty much kept Baltimore in the ballpark -- Adam Jones\' two-run shot in the third inning Saturday is the only Orioles homer in the series.Kansas City has one stolen base and that\'s been irrelevant to either result. Baltimore has cut down Jarrod Dyson as a pinch-runner in the seventh inning of both games so far \xe2\x80\x93once by each catcher, Nick Hundley and Caleb Joseph.Gore scored the winning run as a pinch-runner but he merely was sacrificed to second by Mike Moustakas and scored easily on Escobar\'s hit.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } Royals perfect in postseason, take 2-0 ALCS leadThe game will change in Kansas City\'s more spacious ballpark, where there are fewer homers and more space for what\'s already been a remarkable string of outfield defensive plays from the Royals.The harsh reality for Baltimore is that what really needs to change is starting pitching.Only one Orioles starter this postseason has recorded as much as an out in the sixth inning, and that was Bud Norris, who won Baltimore\'s Division Series clincher against Detroit but was hit hard and often Saturday.Baltimore\'s starters have averaged 4 2/3 innings in their five games."It changes the tempo of the game," says Orioles manager Buck Showalter, whose team has wiped out Kansas City leads in both games but has never led.The Orioles\' shortest outing of the postseason  was from Wei-Yin Chen, who starts Game 3 in Kansas City on Monday. Chen was knocked out by Detroit with two outs in the fourth inning of Division Series Game 2 but Baltimore won that day thanks to another Tigers bullpen meltdown.You can\'t count on that against Kansas City, which again deployed Kelvin Herrera, Wade Davis and Greg Holland to rule the final three innings.But if there ever was a day to make a dent on that Royal relief corps, this was it.Kansas City starting pitcher Yordano Ventura left two outs into the sixth because of shoulder tightness. He said after the game that he left as a precaution, didn\'t feel any lasting effects and didn\'t expect he\'s even need an MRI.  The four runs, five hits and three walks he allowed hardly made for an overwhelming performance but he was giving Royals manager Ned Yost what was needed most.Yost obviously was hoping to go as deep as he could with Ventura, considering Davis pitched two innings Friday and Herrera nearly two. Minimizing their work certainly would help going into Sunday\'s off-day.Rookie Brandon Finnegan finished the sixth and Yost boldly went back to his battle-tested formula for a second consecutive day in a tie game.When Herrera missed first base on what should have been the first out of the seventh and walked the next batter, he looked plenty vulnerable. He struck out Jones and then the Kansas City defense made more significant contributions.Nelson Cruz singled, but the reputation of hard-charging left fielder Alex Gordon kept Nick Markakis from even attempting to score from second and give the Orioles their first lead of the series.After Herrera got Steve Pearce on a short fly to left, J.J. Hardy sent a fly toward the right field line. But there was Lorenzo Cain, who already had made his mark with a diving catch in center field the previous inning.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } Royals pitcher Ventura exits ALCS game with injury"There\'s such a difference in him from last year," Davis says of the 24-year-old Herrera not panicking in a tight spot mostly of his own doing. "His approach is much less jittery now. I\'m not worried about him with that stuff. Now, he\'s getting movement on pitches that are already 100 mph. I\'ve never seen anything like it."Davis hadn\'t seen anything like his own effort in quite awhile. He pitched more than an inning just four times this season and not since May 29. And each time he did, he had the next day off \xe2\x80\x93 at least three days each time he had pitched two full innings.But this is October and the way Davis is going, you can count Jonathan Schoop\'s two-out bouncing single through the middle as a rally. That\'s all Baltimore managed in the eighth."I do all sorts of exercises all day to try to be ready," Davis says. "And with crowds like this, you really push through."And this was a road game.The Kauffman Stadium crowds probably won\'t be any more or less raucous, but the impact of offense changes with the next two or three games in Kansas City. If it\'s only two, much of this becomes moot in a hurry and we need to be more concerned about the Royals\' match-up with the remaining National League teams.But the Royals hitters like to remind you Kauffman Stadium is a factor in major league low home run total."We play in a big ballpark," says Kansas City left fielder Gordon. "Our ballpark kind of fits our team as far as pitching and defense and our speed in the outfield.  We like our ballpark.  It\'s not a home run-happy ballpark, but it definitely finds gaps and we hit a lot more doubles (fourth-most in the AL, seventh in the majors) than maybe some other people do.  It is what it is, and we like it."Just like this ALCS so far.GALLERY: Orioles, Royals battle in ALCSCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Gazing at Statues of Greats, Adam Jones Pours a Foundation ...', '     Supported by    Baseball  Gazing at Statues of Greats, Adam Jones Pours a Foundation of His Own    On Baseball  By                       TYLER KEPNER   OCT. 10, 2014     Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }         Photo       Of all the players in the A.L.C.S., Adam Jones (10) has the most All-Star selections, with four.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 The American League Championship Series is at once a victory and a challenge for Major League Baseball.It is the last A.L.C.S. in the long reign of Commissioner Bud Selig, who speaks often of the virtues of competitive balance and is set to leave with two perennial also-rans, the Baltimore Orioles and the Kansas City Royals, meeting for the pennant. But it is also the first with Derek Jeter as a retired player.Jeter, as the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 captain and a marketable champion, was famous in a way few ballplayers are. This postseason has offered a chance for some of baseball\xe2\x80\x99s most recognizable young stars to take the stage. But Mike Trout, Andrew McCutchen, Clayton Kershaw and Bryce Harper have gone home early.\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Trout, let\xe2\x80\x99s not kid ourselves \xe2\x80\x94 he\xe2\x80\x99s the face of baseball,\xe2\x80\x9d Adam Jones, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 center fielder, said. \xe2\x80\x9cMan, the kid\xe2\x80\x99s unbelievable. He can play, flat-out.\xe2\x80\x9d Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      So he can, and Camden Yards is where Trout made his most gravity-defying catch, as a rookie in 2012, above the center-field wall. That is Jones\xe2\x80\x99s neighborhood, and this series gives him a chance to welcome more fans to it than ever before.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jones dismissed the idea that he was even the face of the Orioles, citing right fielder Nick Markakis, who has been here two years longer, as the soul of the team. But of all the players in the A.L.C.S., Jones has the most All-Star selections, with four. Only 10 other players on the rosters have been selected even once.Fame is finding Jones. In the past month, he has appeared on the covers of ESPN the Magazine and Sports Illustrated (regionally, shared with a hockey player). He has 155,000 followers on Twitter and more than 82,000 on Instagram. He said he recognized that the players remaining in the postseason could showcase themselves, but his ambitions sounded more local.\xe2\x80\x9cWe were talking about the statues, the six out there,\xe2\x80\x9d Jones said, referring to a conversation with Manager Buck Showalter about the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 greats in an outfield plaza.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThey all have two things in common: First, they\xe2\x80\x99re all winners, they all got hardware, a ring; and they\xe2\x80\x99re all Hall of Famers. They won\xe2\x80\x99t make statues just for very good players. They\xe2\x80\x99ll make them for the greats. If you want to be in that, this is the time to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  People here know the super six without thinking: Brooks and Frank Robinson, Jim Palmer, Earl Weaver, Eddie Murray and Cal Ripken. Jones, 29, is not among their ranks and does not pretend he is. But he is the highest-paid Oriole (six years, $85.5 million) and perhaps the most charismatic. Fans feel as if they know him.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s comfortable sharing part of his life with fans, and that makes him unusual,\xe2\x80\x9d reliever Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s not afraid to kind of put himself out there and let his opinion be heard, and he\xe2\x80\x99s proud of who he is. There\xe2\x80\x99s not a lot of guys who are that comfortable in their own skin to do that. That sets him apart.\xe2\x80\x9dSo does his game. Jones is a good bet for roughly 30 homers and 100 runs batted in every season and has missed just five games, total, in the past three years. He has won three Gold Glove awards and plays a shallow center field \xe2\x80\x94 a sign, O\xe2\x80\x99Day said, of a player more concerned with saving pitchers from cheap hits than positioning himself for desperate attempts at balls sailing over the fence. Privacy Policy     \xe2\x80\x9cThe guy you jam, or the guy who hits it off the end of the bat, that\xe2\x80\x99s where I want my out,\xe2\x80\x9d O\xe2\x80\x99Day said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s how big innings are created, with that little bloop over the infield. Jonesy\xe2\x80\x99s getting that ball and taking that hit away.\xe2\x80\x9dJones said his brother, Anson, had told him there was no method to his madness as a hitter. Some days, he comes to the plate hacking; other times, he waits for his pitch. Generally, though, Jones is aggressive, like most of the Orioles. He averaged fewer than one walk per week this season, with a .311 on-base percentage.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jones\xe2\x80\x99s baseball role model also did not walk much, but otherwise they were different hitters. Growing up in San Diego, Jones idolized the Padres\xe2\x80\x99 Tony Gwynn and signed a letter of intent to play for Gwynn when he was the coach at San Diego State. Jones instead signed as a first-round pick of the Seattle Mariners, but he worked out in the winters with Gwynn, who made a lasting impression before he died in June.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe had fun playing the game,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jones, who sometimes blows bubbles while chasing fly balls. \xe2\x80\x9cHey, man, this game is frustrating as it is. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a one-man game; it\xe2\x80\x99s a team game. So he always told me, \xe2\x80\x98Do what you can do to impact the game, have some fun and live with the results.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9dThe Mariners drafted Jones as a shortstop, the position he played for three minor league seasons. He switched to the outfield in 2006, at age 20, and reached the majors. He was wide-eyed and eager to learn, said the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 Raul Ibanez, a teammate then.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Luckily for the Orioles, the Mariners flirted with contention in 2007, despite allowing more runs than they scored. Eager to build on a fluky season, Seattle traded Jones and four others, including starter Chris Tillman, to Baltimore for starter Erik Bedard.\xe2\x80\x9cYou knew that you lost a great player when you traded him,\xe2\x80\x9d Ibanez said.It was robbery for the Orioles and an opportunity for Jones, who said he first lamented the deal because the Orioles were so bad. By then, they had staggered through 10 losing seasons in a row, a streak that finally ended under Showalter in 2012. That season, Jones signed his contract and gave up free agency.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI could have got more,\xe2\x80\x9d Jones said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou test free agency, you can do whatever you want then. But what it was, was Buck\xe2\x80\x99s commitment. For some reason, me and him, we meshed right away. The second we met, our styles fit each other. A lot of people told me you get one great manager in your career, and if you\xe2\x80\x99re able to stick with him, stick with him.\xe2\x80\x9dShowalter said Jones made him laugh two or three times a day. In a meeting, he said, Jones once did a spot-on impersonation of him; Showalter was amazed that Jones could pick up so many details and mannerisms. He is smart, Showalter said, a keen observer who misses nothing and sets the example Showalter wanted when he took over in 2010.\xe2\x80\x9cThe way he played had to match up with what we needed him to be about, and it has since the first week I was here,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s made my job a lot easier.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jones could make things easier for baseball\xe2\x80\x99s marketers, too, by leading a desperate team to the World Series.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 The Kansas City Royals are so hot right now, perhaps only a long layoff can stop them. You can almost see it coming: The Royals could sweep the American League Championship Series, sit around for a while and then crash back to earth in the World Series. The 2007 Colorado Rockies would get lots of phone calls from reporters seeking to make a comparison.The problem for the Baltimore Orioles is that the A.L.C.S. stops for only one day before resuming at Kauffman Stadium on Monday. The Orioles are down, two games to none, and never held a lead in Games 1 and 2 at Camden Yards. The Royals, meanwhile, are 6-0 in the postseason.\xe2\x80\x9cThe series ain\xe2\x80\x99t over,\xe2\x80\x9d the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Adam Jones said near his locker after the game. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you guys are thinking it\xe2\x80\x99s over, why are we going to show up on Monday? We\xe2\x80\x99ve got a lot of baseball to play in this series. Let\xe2\x80\x99s get back after it. We\xe2\x80\x99re going to go to K.C. \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99ve been a very good team on the road \xe2\x80\x94 so let\xe2\x80\x99s go there and have some fun. Eat some barbecue.\xe2\x80\x9dThe barbecue will taste great, but nothing else about the trip is certain. Even when the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 pitchers execute their plan, they have learned that the Royals are still apt to foil it. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      It happened in Game 1 on Friday, when Alex Gordon drove in three runs in the third inning on a broken-bat double off Chris Tillman. It happened again in the first inning of Game 2, when Eric Hosmer broke his bat on a blooper just over the glove of shortstop J. J. Hardy, scoring two runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Royals deserve credit for putting the runners on base, and Lorenzo Cain, who scored from second, had a heady read on Hosmer\xe2\x80\x99s hit, allowing Cain to race home. But as two-run singles go, this was maddening.\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the pitch I wanted to make, an up-and-in fastball,\xe2\x80\x9d starter Bud Norris said. He added later: \xe2\x80\x9cGot to let it go; nothing you can control. We know we played a hard nine innings.\xe2\x80\x9dIndeed, the Orioles brought the winning run to the plate at the end of Game 1, and the tying run to the plate at the end of Game 2. They have fought back three times to draw even in these games but have never quite shaken the Royals.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the big key, if we want to win this series, is when we get that momentum, keeping it on our side,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles closer Zach Britton said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd they\xe2\x80\x99re a younger team. If we can do that, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be in a good spot. But a young team playing hot right now, they have all the confidence in the world. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got to kind of put them into a corner a little bit, and that comes from scoring runs, getting the momentum on our side and then shutting them down.\xe2\x80\x9d Newsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story [{"headline":"Sports","summary":"Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, delivered to your inbox every week.","product-code":"SP","product-title":"Sports","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/sports?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=SP&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Race\\/Related Newsletter","summary":"Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with New York Times journalists.","product-code":"RR","product-title":"Race Related","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/race-related?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=RR&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Your Money","summary":"Every week, get tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest.","product-code":"MY","product-title":"Your Money","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/your-money?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=business&contentId=MY&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"}]      Please verify you\'re not a robot by clicking the box. Privacy Policy     Britton walked the bases loaded in the ninth inning of Game 1 and said later he was surprised by the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 plate discipline; he expected them to swing more often than they did. It was a reasonable guess, because the Royals are an extreme contact-hitting team. Their hitters ranked last in the majors in strikeouts this season, with just 985. The next-closest team, Oakland, struck out 119 more times.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In this series, the strikeouts have been nearly even \xe2\x80\x94 17 for the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 hitters, 16 for the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 hitters. But when Kansas City makes contact, good fortune follows. An infield single by the speedy Cain led to a run in the third, and another by Omar Infante led to the go-ahead run in the ninth, on a double by Alcides Escobar.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThey do a good job of putting the ball in play, and once that happens, you can\xe2\x80\x99t control where the balls are, or what happens,\xe2\x80\x9d said Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day, the losing pitcher in both games. \xe2\x80\x9cSo credit them for doing that. I threw some good pitches, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll wear the loss.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Royals have also hit home runs, another category in which they ranked last in the major leagues this season. It had little to do with their expansive home park, either; the Royals ranked 29th of 30 teams in homers on the road.At Camden Yards, though, they have flexed their power at critical points, just as they did in Anaheim, while sweeping the Los Angeles Angels in the last round. Escobar, Gordon and Mike Moustakas homered in Game 1 on Friday, and Moustakas homered again in the fourth inning of Game 2, just after Baltimore had tied the score.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cWe can swing the bats on this side,\xe2\x80\x9d Moustakas said after Game 1. \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t always have to play small ball.\xe2\x80\x9d  But they still do that well, and for all the power he has shown in these playoffs, Moustakas was still asked to drop a sacrifice bunt to move the pinch-runner Terrance Gore into scoring position in the ninth inning on Saturday. He did the job, and Gore scored the winning run.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re a scrappy ball club, and we knew that coming in,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Steve Pearce. \xe2\x80\x9cRight now, they\xe2\x80\x99re getting timely hits and they\xe2\x80\x99re starting off fast; they\xe2\x80\x99ve had early leads in both games. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got to go to their place and stun them like they did us.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on October 12, 2014, on Page SP2 of the New York edition with the headline: Reeling Orioles Look to Right Themselves on the Road. MAY 1       See More \xc2\xbb       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: What A Great Opportunity!', 'Oct 11, 2014; Baltimore, MD, USA; Baltimore Orioles players watch from the dugout during game two of the 2014 ALCS playoff against the Kansas City Royals at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsThe Kansas City Royals escaped yet another extra-innings playoffs game by beating the Baltimore Orioles on Saturday 6-4, giving them the 2-0 lead in the American League Championship Series.Kansas CityRoyals6BaltimoreOrioles4It was another frustrating game for the O\xe2\x80\x99s who battled back but could never get over the hump and take the lead. Having made a reputation over this season for the capacity to fight back, being unable to consummate it is vexing \xe2\x80\x93 both to the team and the fans who watch.The Orioles are hitting the ball \xe2\x80\x93 batting .291 over the two games. But the Royals are hitting even better (.329) and are doing so at more opportune times.It is difficult for the pitching staff of the O\xe2\x80\x99s to be constantly throwing from the stretch, and that is not far from the truth. The Royals have had baserunners in 18 out of 19 innings over these two games. Only the eighth inning on Saturday were they set down 1-2-3. By contrast, the Orioles have gone down in order five times.Frankly, the Orioles right now are playing a very good team that is performing at the top of their game. Alex Gordon and Lorenzo Cain are not just baseball players, they are good athletes. And Mike Moustakas has found a grove with a very pretty swing. These guys are good, they are making all the plays, and the ball is bouncing well for them as well. They\xe2\x80\x99ve got it goin\xe2\x80\x99 on.But the Baltimore Orioles have a great opportunity here to really establish themselves and this 2014 team as a historically great team. It would be even better yet if they could lose the next game and battle back from a 3-0 deficit.Has that ever happened before in the ALCS? Yes! In fact, it was a decade ago in 2004.With the Yankees leading the Red Sox 3-0, the Series turned when Boston hit a walk-off homer in the bottom of the ninth inning in game 4.\xc2\xa0 Three games later, the Curse of the Bambino was broken, and the Sox went on to sweep the Cardinals in the World Series.Why not sweep back on the Royals and sweep the Cardinals again?To do that, the starters are going to need to go deeper, and the Orioles are going to need some production from the fifth and sixth spots in the order \xe2\x80\x93 Steve Pearce and J.J. Hardy.So it could be the end, or it could be the beginning of the end \xe2\x80\x93 an ending that is epic.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 Shortly after the Kansas City Royals won Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Friday, Mike Moustakas, who had homered in the 10th inning of that game, was asked what he preferred, long ball or small ball.The question was a reference to style of play \xe2\x80\x94 one that relies on power or one in which runs are manufactured through clever base running, bunting and hit-and-run plays. Moustakas said he did not have a preference as long as the Royals won.But lately, Moustakas and the Royals seem capable of winning every possible way: through power, speed, defense or their stockpile of high-voltage arms.Moustakas showed his versatility in Game 2 by hitting his fourth home run in six postseason games and then laying down a perfect bunt that helped push the go-ahead run into scoring position with the score tied in the ninth. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Add to his performance Lorenzo Cain\xe2\x80\x99s all-around excellence, and the Royals won, 6-4, on Saturday to take a commanding 2-0 lead in the best-of-seven series, winning both games on the road.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Royals also extended their postseason winning streak to nine games, dating from the 1985 World Series, their last appearance in the postseason before this year. The last time they lost was Oct. 23, 1985, when John Tudor of the St. Louis Cardinals tossed a five-hit shutout in Game 4 of that memorable series.Three decades later, Cain went 4 for 5 with two runs scored on Saturday, drove in a run in the ninth inning and made two critical, athletic catches in the outfield.\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a game changer,\xe2\x80\x9d Moustakas said. \xe2\x80\x9cAny time he\xe2\x80\x99s in that lineup, he changes the game.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Afterward, both teams were packing up to travel West for Game 3 in Kansas City on Monday, which lands 29 years to the day since Game 5 of the 1985 A.L.C.S., the last championship series game played in Kansas City.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIf you can go home 2-0, that\xe2\x80\x99s as good as it gets,\xe2\x80\x9d Royals Manager Ned Yost said. \xe2\x80\x9cGoing home 2-0 with our crowd for the next three days is going to be exciting.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Royals, who won Game 1 in 10 innings, managed to finish this one off in nine, as Omar Infante led off the inning with a single against Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day, who was quickly replaced by Zach Britton, the Orioles left-handed closer. Photo       The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Nick Markakis was safe at first after Royals pitcher Kelvin Herrera took a toss from first baseman Eric Hosmer but missed the bag during the seventh inning.  Credit             Matt Slocum/Associated Press           Yost exchanged Infante for a pinch-runner, Terrence Gore, as Moustakas came to the plate. Even though Moustakas may currently be the most dangerous hitter on the four remaining teams, Yost didn\xe2\x80\x99t want him swinging away against the lefty Britton, and asked him to bunt.Yost is often criticized for his use of such antiquated devices as the sacrifice bunt, but he stuck to his methods, and was quite pleased about the outcome.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThat was the direction we took, and it worked out great for us,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.Everything seems to work out great for them, right now. Privacy Policy     The next batter, shortstop Alcides Escobar, punched a double down the right-field line and Gore scored to give the Royals the lead, 5-4. Jarrod Dyson reached on an error and Cain singled up the middle, pushing home Escobar with an insurance run that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even needed.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Cain, the Royals\xe2\x80\x99 center fielder, also exhibited his terrific defensive skills by making a diving catch of J. J. Hardy\xe2\x80\x99s line drive on a flat sprint into right field. He was then shifted to right field in the next inning and robbed Hardy again, this time with the bases loaded and two outs, the score even.\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the keys is probably the two plays that Cain made in the outfield,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles Manager Buck Showalter said, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause he makes one in the center, then moving to right, and makes one there. I expected him to make one in left field before the game was over.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Yordano Ventura started for the Royals and gave up four runs. He left with two outs in the sixth with some stiffness and fatigue in his right shoulder, he said, but did not expect it to keep him from pitching again, if needed.Bud Norris, who pitched so well for the Orioles in the clinching game against the Detroit Tigers in the division series Monday, was not as sharp on Saturday. He allowed four runs and nine hits in four and a third innings. One of those hits was the home run by Moustakas, who tied Willie Mays Aikens for most home runs by a Royals player in one postseason. Aikens hit his four homers in 1980.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThe only stat that matters is the one in the win column,\xe2\x80\x9d Moustakas said, \xe2\x80\x9cand we\xe2\x80\x99ve been doing pretty well in that.\xe2\x80\x9dSo well, in fact, that the Orioles must win four of the next five games to stay alive. It has been a surprising and difficult opening to the series for Showalter and the Orioles, who have not led in any of the games. (\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve been tied,\xe2\x80\x9d he pointed out, searching for a positive).But both games have been so close that, even though the Royals have a reassuring lead heading home, the Orioles may feel they are in a position to do the same thing in Kansas City that the Royals did here.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of confidence in our guys,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can see this time of year what a sharp, razor-thin line there is between the two. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got to earn everything, every inning, every at-bat.\xe2\x80\x9d   Correction: October 14, 2014           An article on Sunday about the Kansas City Royals\xe2\x80\x99 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series misidentified the Orioles pitcher who gave up the hit to Omar Infante as he led off the ninth inning in a 4-4 game. The pitcher was Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day, who was charged with the loss \xe2\x80\x94 not Zach Britton, who replaced O\xe2\x80\x99Day after the hit. [('Open Letter To The Baltimore Orioles \\xab CBS Baltimore', ' Dear Baltimore Orioles, You Are In the ALCS!\xc2\xa0 How are ya holding up? I know it\xe2\x80\x99s been a rough couple of days. That\xe2\x80\x99s weird to say considering you\xe2\x80\x99re in the American League Championship Series, but these aren\xe2\x80\x99t normal circumstances. For starters, you won the AL East when practically no one outside of Baltimore gave you a fighting chance to do so. Of course once you do, people just shrug it off as a down year for the real teams in the East. You know, those Yankees and Red Sox \xe2\x80\x94 the guys with the money. The pundits figured you\xe2\x80\x99d just fade away in the ALDS to the Cy Young Tigers \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, the Detroit Tigers. But you swept them. You swept a playoff team and moonwalked right into the ALCS. Your City Loves You\xc2\xa0 Had to feel good huh? Those same critics hopping on your bandwagon and basically handing you a ticket to the World Series. The city loved you, the pundits loved you, and perhaps the world loved you. But What\xe2\x80\x99s Going On?\xc2\xa0 And then you actually played baseball \xe2\x80\x93 and you lost. Twice! At home! Now the bandwagon is empty and the pundits are saying you\xe2\x80\x99re done. Where have we seen this before? Of course it\xe2\x80\x99s disappointing that you\xe2\x80\x99re down 0-2 in the series. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean you\xe2\x80\x99re dead. That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean you\xe2\x80\x99re out of this thing. The beautiful thing about baseball is that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t end when you lose. You have to dust yourself off, put your cleats on, and get back out there for another game. You lost 66 games this season \xe2\x80\x93 2 more won\xe2\x80\x99t kill you. I Know You Won\xe2\x80\x99t Give Up And please don\xe2\x80\x99t think I believe you\xe2\x80\x99re giving up. I know you too well for that. You guys represent what Baltimore is all about. You\xe2\x80\x99re tough, gritty, and full of pride. You want this just as much as the fans want this. I\xe2\x80\x99ve watched the Ravens capture the hearts of the citizens of Baltimore over the past 20 years. But the Orioles have something the Ravens may never have \xe2\x80\x94 their souls. You saw the passion during the ALDS Series. You feel the energy when you walk around Downtown Baltimore. And now you get to take that passion to Kansas City. You have the opportunity to show the Royals and the rest of the country why you made it this far. \xc2\xa0 Chris Tillman isn\xe2\x80\x99t the best pitcher in the MLB, but he may be one of the smartest. He\xe2\x80\x99s never out of it, even when the bases are loaded with nobody out. Nelson Cruz swings the bat better than most men on the planet. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got a bullpen that can shut down the opposition. And you\xe2\x80\x99ve got stars in the outfield like Adam Jones and Nick Markakis ready to dive for any ball that comes their way. The talent is there to get the job done and you have the best manager in the business to show you the way. All you have to do is get out there and take it. \xc2\xa0 As a writer it\xe2\x80\x99s frustrating reading other journalist count you out just because you lost a game or 2. But I quickly realize that their opinions mean little. If their opinions mattered that much, it\xe2\x80\x99d be the Red Sox playing the Royals, not the Baltimore Orioles. \xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s Time To Make Baseball Fun Again The games you lost in Baltimore were highly competitive and entertaining. You weren\xe2\x80\x99t skull dragged into submission. You weren\xe2\x80\x99t embarrassed on national television. You lost to a good baseball team \xe2\x80\x93 it happens. But now you get to the fun part. Now you get to take the pride of Baltimore with you to Kansas City and take the fight to them. You get to win at least 2 of the next 3 games in Kansas City to gain back the momentum. And then you get to come home and finish this thing. \xc2\xa0 The pundits may think the series is over but it\xe2\x80\x99s just getting started. But you already knew that.  Samuel Njoku was born and raised in Baltimore, MD and is a graduate of the University of Maryland Eastern Shore. Samuel has covered the Ravens for Examiner.com since 2010. Prior to 2010, Samuel was an avid blogger and radio personality in Salisbury, MD. Samuel Njoku is a freelance writer covering all things NFL. His work can be found on Examiner.com. You can also follow him on Twitter @Ravens_Examiner.    ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com'), ('MLB postpones Game 3 of Royals-Orioles ALCS - USA Today', 'Kauffman Stadium may be drenched in rain by the time Game 3 of the AL Championship Series rolls around.(Photo: Charlie Riedel, AP)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREKANSAS CITY \xe2\x80\x93 The impact of Monday\'s rainout of Game 3 of the American League Championship Series might not be known for several days \xe2\x80\x93 and the Baltimore Orioles can only hope they make a dent in Kansas City\'s 2-0 advantage and get to find out.Day-long downpours bumped back a day the schedule for the middle portion of the series at Kansas City\'s Kauffman Stadium, making Game 3 Tuesday at 8:07 p.m. ET, followed by games Wednesday and possibly Thursday at 4:07 ET.Thursday\'s scheduled off day would be eliminated and the series would continue as planned Friday in Baltimore \xe2\x80\x93 if it gets that far.     .oembed-asset-link { border-bottom: 1px solid #e1e1e1; }     .oembed-link-anchor { display: block; clear: both; }     p.oembed-link-desc { font-size: 100%; color: #666; font-weight: normal; margin: 0 14px 14px 14px; font-family: \'Futura Today Light\'; text-align: left; line-height: 120%; } Built to win: Royals ready for final challengeBoth managers will stick with their planned Game 3 starters \xe2\x80\x93 Jeremy Guthrie for the Royals and Wei-Yin Chen for the Orioles but neither Kansas City\'s Ned Yost nor Baltimore\'s Buck Showalter would commit beyond that.The postponement would allow the Game 1 starters to pitch Game 4 on their normal rest."I wouldn\'t commit to anything beyond (Chen)," Showalter said. "We\'ll see where we are."He could go back to No. 1 Chris Tillman for Game 4 but he\'ll still need to use all four of his starters to come back and win the series.Yost said he probably will decide on Game 4 before Game 3 is played but noted that bullpen use becomes every bit as crucial with the potential of games five days in a row."We pushed then a number of times late in the season to two and three days in a row and they responded fine," Yost said of closer Greg Holland and key set-up men Wade Davis and Kelvin Herrera. "It gets a little more like regular season."Holland pitched on three consecutive days four times this season and had a blown save in one of those third games. He even had a stretch of five games in six days and did not allow an earned run.Davis also did three in a row four times, allowing a run in the third game the first time he did it in April but cruising through the other instances. The Royals were more careful with the 24-year-old Herrera. He never was in three consecutive games and had just one stretch in May when he was in four games in five days and five in seven. The most notable effect for Herrera was three walks in the last of those games.Showalter had spread the workload among his set-up corps but closer Zach Britton, while pitching three consecutive days just twice, had seven instances of three games in four days. Of his four blown saves this season, one came in a third appearance in a row, another at the end of two three-game-in-four-days stretches about a week apart.For Baltimore, just easing the bullpen role in general will be crucial to staying in this series. Orioles starters have gotten as much as one out in the sixth inning just once in six post-season games and are averaging less than five innings per start.***The schedule for the remaining three games in Kansas City:Game 3, Tuesday: 8:07 ET start.Game 4, Wednesday: 4:07 ET start.Game 5, Thursday, if necessary: 4:07 ET start.Major League Baseball announced that fans holding tickets to Game 3 will use them Tuesday, and likewise for Game 4 and 5 ticketholders.GALLERY: Royals and Orioles in the ALCSCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Charming Home Seems Cursed for the Orioles', '     Supported by    Baseball  Charming Home Seems Cursed for the Orioles    Sports of The Times  By                       JULIET MACUR   OCT. 12, 2014     Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                  if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }         Photo       The Orioles have hosted 16 playoff games over all since Camden Yards opened in 1992, winning only seven.                     });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 It was hard not to cringe when the Baltimore Orioles remained upbeat on Saturday after losing their second straight game at home to the Kansas City Royals in the American League Championship Series.\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no need to hit the panic button,\xe2\x80\x9d Caleb Joseph, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 catcher, said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll get things done in Kansas City, win a couple of games there, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll be back here to win in front of our fans.\xe2\x80\x9dBud Norris, the Baltimore pitcher who started Saturday, said all he needed to do was review some film and regroup. Then he would be ready to get the ball again for Game 6, he said, and close out the series with a victory here at Camden Yards.I wanted to believe them. Who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t? The Orioles had one of the better records at home during the regular season, going 50-31. They have shown the chutzpah that likable teams are made of, running away with their division even after losing some star power down the stretch. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      And, yes, the Orioles can win at least two of three playoff games on the road, beating a Royals team that has yet to lose this postseason, then return home to clinch the series and take their franchise to its first World Series in 31 years.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  It can certainly happen in this sport, in which an unexpected bounce can change a team\xe2\x80\x99s fortunes. But it isn\xe2\x80\x99t likely to happen when a team can\xe2\x80\x99t win big games in its own ballpark.The Orioles have hosted eight A.L.C.S. games since Camden Yards opened in 1992, and they have won only one of those games. They have hosted 16 playoff games over all in that stretch, winning only seven.So even if they sweep the Royals in Kansas City to take the lead in this series, the odds are stacked against the Orioles.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  It\xe2\x80\x99s as if they missed the memo regarding home-field advantage.How is it that come October, the Orioles struggle to win in their own ballpark?  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s the fans. Could they be scared that they will put all their energy into a team that will disappoint again?  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  One fan, Sarah Robinson, 27, who called herself the Baltimore Bird Lady, glared at me through her plumage when it was suggested that fans should take some of the blame.For the past three years, Robinson has been attending Orioles home games dressed as, well, an Oriole: with a Mardi Gras mask covered with orange, white and black feathers; giant black wings painted Orioles colors; orange and black fuzzy leg warmers; and more feathers adorning her hair.\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not our fault. Not at all.\xe2\x80\x9dIf the fans are worried about their team, they are doing all they can to will it to a win.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Nearly 47,000 fans packed the ballpark Saturday, arriving like a tangerine army, in bright orange shirts and hats. Orange towels were handed out at the gate, and fans waved them so wildly it was as if they were on a remote island trying to flag down a passing ship. Privacy Policy     It was a beautiful sight, especially in this ballpark, one of the league\xe2\x80\x99s finest, which deserves more from its players, if they make it back home. A baseball gem, Oriole Park at Camden Yards was the first of its kind: a stadium with an old-time atmosphere and modern amenities, all integrated seamlessly into the city.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  A renovated warehouse from the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad provided the backdrop in right field. Fans could see the jagged city skyline peeking from behind the outfield walls, and the Inner Harbor \xe2\x80\x94 with tall ships to see and crab cakes to devour \xe2\x80\x94 is a close walk.An entire city street was included in the ballpark\xe2\x80\x99s design, becoming a pedestrian walkway dotted by vendors hawking things from Polish sausages to Orioles pennants.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  While other stadiums were mostly all-purpose facilities, sterile and without personality, Camden Yards set the blueprint for nearly every new major league ballpark since.But it is not without one notable flaw: A statue of Babe Ruth outside the center-field gate was cast with Ruth holding a right-handed fielder\xe2\x80\x99s glove. Except that Ruth batted left-handed and threw left-handed. The error was caught too late to fix.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  What would Ruth think of his statute, right-handed fielder\xe2\x80\x99s glove and all, and a team hardly able to win postseason games in its own house?Ruth was born a few blocks from the spot of his statue, and in 1914 he signed with the Baltimore Orioles, a minor league team at the time. That year, he was sold to the Boston Red Sox and began his career in the majors.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Five years later, Ruth was sold to the Yankees, which was the crux of what was called the Curse of the Bambino, supposedly leading to an 86-year drought between World Series titles for the Red Sox.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  So how about Ruth\xe2\x80\x99s sale to the Red Sox from the Orioles? Did that come with a curse, too, with the flaw in Ruth\xe2\x80\x99s statue the tipping point that has now vexed the Orioles in their quest to reach the World Series?Just a thought. The Orioles, of course, will say none of this matters. Forget that their chances of a win at home are about 1 in 10 \xe2\x80\x94 judging by past performances.  These Orioles are a positive bunch, the kind of guys who could be down two laps to the leader in the Daytona 500, one tire flat and front fender flapping in the air, and still believe they could cross the finish line first. Or who could be playing without a goalie in the World Cup and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t concede, even for a minute, that it might hamper their route to the final.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  That kind of confidence \xe2\x80\x94 or na\xc3\xafvet\xc3\xa9, depending on how you look at it \xe2\x80\x94 is sweet, but it might not be sweet enough to deliver a win at home.  Email: juliet@nytimes.com  A version of this article appears in print on October 13, 2014, on Page D2 of the New York edition with the headline: Charming Home Seems Cursed for the Orioles.
